books.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1:1
verses.text: Sacred History, Book II: Chapter I.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1:2
verses.text: The times of the captivity have been rendered illustrious by the predictions and deeds of the prophets, and especially by the remarkable persistency of Daniel in upholding the law, and by the deliverance of Susanna through the divine wisdom, as well as by the other things which it accomplished, and which we shall now relate in their order, Daniel was made a prisoner under King Joachim, and was brought to Babylon, while still a very little child.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1:3
verses.text: Afterwards, on account of the beauty of his countenance, he had a place given him among the king's servants, and along with him, Annanias, Misael, and Azarias.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1:4
verses.text: But, when the king had ordered them to be supplied with the finer kinds of food, and had imposed it as a duty on Asphane the eunuch to attend to that matter, Daniel, mindful of the traditions of his fathers which forbade him to partake of food from the table of a king of the Gentiles, begged of the eunuch to be allowed to use a diet of pulse only.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1:5
verses.text: Asphane objected that the leanness which would follow might reveal the fact that the king's commandment had been disobeyed; but Daniel, putting his trust in God, promised that he would have greater beauty of countenance from living on pulse than from the use of the king's dainties.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1:6
verses.text: And his words were made good, so that the faces of those who were cared for at the public expense were regarded as by no means comparable to those of Daniel and his friends.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1:7
verses.text: Accordingly, being promoted by the king to honor and favor, they were, in a short time, by their prudence and wise conduct, preferred to all those that stood nearest to the king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1:8
verses.text: About the same time, Susanna, the wife of a certain man called Joachis, a woman of remarkable beauty, was desired by two elders, and, when she would not listen to their unchaste proposals, was assailed by a false accusation.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1:9
verses.text: These elders reported that a young man was found with her in a retired place, but escaped their hands by his youthful nimbleness, while they were enfeebled with age.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1:10
verses.text: Credit, accordingly, was given to these elders, and Susanna was condemned by the sentence of the people.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1:11
verses.text: And, as she was being led away to punishment according to the law, Daniel, who was then twelve years old, after having rebuked the Jews for delivering the innocent to death, demanded that she should be brought back to trial, and that her cause should be heard afresh.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1:12
verses.text: For the multitude of the Jews who were then present, thought that a boy of an age so little commanding respect, had not ventured to take such a bold step without a divine impulse, and, granting him the favor which was asked, returned anew to council.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1:13
verses.text: The trial, then, is entered upon once more; and Daniel was allowed to take his place among the elders.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1:14
verses.text: Upon this, he orders the two accusers to be separated from each other, and inquires of each of them in turn, under what kind of a tree he had discovered the adulteress.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 1:15
verses.text: From the difference of answers which they gave, their falsehood was detected: Susanna was acquitted; and the elders, who had brought the innocent into danger, were condemned to death.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 2

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 2:2
verses.text: At that time, Nabuchodonosor had a dream marvelous for that insight into the future which it implied.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 2:3
verses.text: As he could not of himself bring out its interpretation, he sent for the Chaldaeans who were supposed by magic arts and by the entrails of victims to know secret things, and to predict the future, in order to its interpretation.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 2:4
verses.text: Presently becoming apprehensive lest, in the usual manner of men, they should extract from the dream not what was true, but what would be acceptable to the king, he suppresses the things he had seen, and demands of them that, if a real power of divination was in them, they should relate to him the dream itself; saying that he would then believe their interpretation, if they should first make proof of their skill by relating the dream.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 2:5
verses.text: But they declined attempting so great a difficulty, and confessed that such a thing was not within the reach of human power.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 2:6
verses.text: The king, enraged because, under a false profession of divination, they were mocking men with their errors, while they were compelled by the present case to acknowledge that they had no such knowledge as was pretended, made an exposure of them by means of a royal edict; and all the men professing that art were publicly put to death.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 2:7
verses.text: When Daniel heard of that, he spoke to one of those nearest to the king, and promised to give an account of the dream, as well as supply its interpretation.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 2:8
verses.text: The thing is reported to the king, and Daniel is sent for.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 2:9
verses.text: The mystery had already been revealed to him by God; and so he relates the vision of the king, as well as interprets it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 2:10
verses.text: But this matter demands that we set forth the dream of the king and its interpretation, along with the fulfillment of his words by what followed.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 2:11
verses.text: The king,  then, had seen in his sleep an image with a head of gold, with a breast and arms of silver, with a belly and thighs of brass, with legs of iron, and which in its feet ended partly with iron, and partly with clay.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 2:12
verses.text: But the iron and the clay when blended together could not adhere to each other.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 2:13
verses.text: At last, a stone cut out without hands broke the image to pieces, and the whole, being reduced to dust, was carried away by the wind.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:2
verses.text: Accordingly, as the prophet interpreted the matter, the image which was seen furnished a representation of the world.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:3
verses.text: The golden head is the empire of the Chaldaeans; for we have understood that it was the first and wealthiest.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:4
verses.text: The breast and the arms of silver represent the second kingdom; for Cyrus, after the Chaldaeans and the Medes were conquered, conferred the empire on the Persians.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:5
verses.text: In the brazen belly it is said that the third sovereignty was indicated; and we see that this was fulfilled, for Alexander took the empire from the Persians, and won the sovereignty for the Macedonians.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:6
verses.text: The iron legs point to a fourth power, and that is understood of the Roman empire, which is more powerful than all the kingdoms which were before it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:7
verses.text: But the fact that the feet were partly of iron and partly clay, indicates that the Roman empire is to be divided, so as never to be united.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:8
verses.text: This, too, has been fulfilled, for the Roman state is ruled not by one emperor but by several, and these are always quarreling among themselves, either in actual warfare or by factions.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:9
verses.text: Finally, by the clay and the iron being mixed together, yet never in their substance thoroughly uniting, are shadowed forth those future mixtures of the human race which disagree among themselves, though apparently combined.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:10
verses.text: For it is obvious that the Roman territory is occupied by foreign nations, or rebels, or that it has been given over to those who have surrendered themselves under an appearance of peace.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:11
verses.text: And it is also evident that barbarous nations, and especially Jews, have been commingled with our armies, cities, and provinces; and we thus behold them living among us, yet by no means agreeing to adopt our customs.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:12
verses.text: And the prophets declare that these are the last times.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:13
verses.text: But in the stone cut out without hands, which broke to pieces the gold, silver, brass, iron, and clay, there is a figure of Christ.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:14
verses.text: For he, not born under human conditions (since he was born not of the will of man, but of the will of God), will reduce to nothing that world in which exist earthly kingdoms, and will establish another kingdom, incorruptible and everlasting, that is, the future world, which is prepared for the saints.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:15
verses.text: The faith of some still hesitates about this point only, while they do not believe about things yet to come, though they are convinced of the things that are past.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:16
verses.text: Daniel, then, was presented with many gifts by the king, was set over Babylon and the whole empire, and was held in the highest honor.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:17
verses.text: By his influence, Annanias, Azarias, and Misael were also advanced to the highest dignity and power.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:18
verses.text: About the same time, the remarkable prophecies of Ezekiel came out, the mystery of future things and of the resurrection having been revealed to him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 3:19
verses.text: His book is one of great weight, and deserves to be read with care.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 4

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 4:2
verses.text: But in Judaea, over which, as we have related above, Godolia was set after the destruction of Jerusalem, the Jews taking it very ill that a ruler not of the royal race had been assigned them by the mere will of the conqueror, with a certain Ismael as their leader and instigator of the execrable conspiracy, cut off Godolia by means of treachery while he was at a banquet.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 4:3
verses.text: Those, however, who had no part in the plot, wishing to take steps for avenging the deed, hastily take up arms against Ismael.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 4:4
verses.text: But when he learned that destruction threatened him, leaving the army which he had collected, and with not more than eight companions he fled to the Ammonites.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 4:5
verses.text: Fear, therefore, fell upon the whole people, lest the king of Babylon should avenge the guilt of a few by the destruction of all; for, in addition to Godolia, they had slain many of the Chaldaeans along with him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 4:6
verses.text: They, therefore, form a plan of fleeing into Egypt, but they first go in a body to Jeremia, requesting of him divine counsel.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 4:7
verses.text: He then exhorted them all in the words of God to remain in their native country, telling them that if they did so, they would be protected by the power of God, and that no danger would accrue from the Babylonians, but that, if they went into Egypt, they would all perish there by sword, and famine, and different kinds of death.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 4:8
verses.text: The rabble, however, with the usual evil tendency they show, being unaccustomed to yield to useful advice and the divine power, did go into Egypt.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 4:9
verses.text: The sacred Scriptures are silent as to their future fate; and I have not been able to discover anything regarding it.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 5

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 5:2
verses.text: At this period of time, Nabuchodonosor elated with prosperity, erected a golden statue to himself of enormous size, and ordered it to be worshiped as a sacred image.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 5:3
verses.text: And when this was zealously gone about by all, inasmuch as their minds had been corrupted by the universal flattery which prevailed, Annanias, Azarias, and Misael kept aloof from the profane observance, being well aware that that honor was due to God alone.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 5:4
verses.text: They were therefore, according to an edict of the king, regarded as criminals, and there was set before them, as the means of punishment, a fiery furnace, in order that, by present terror, they might be compelled to worship the statue.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 5:5
verses.text: But they preferred to be swallowed up by the flames rather than to commit such a sin.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 5:6
verses.text: Accordingly, they were bound, and cast into the midst of the fire.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 5:7
verses.text: But the flames laid hold of the agents in this execrable work, as they were forcing, with all eagerness, the victims into the fire; while—wonderful to say, and indeed incredible to all but eye-witnesses—the fire did not touch the Hebrews at all.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 5:8
verses.text: They were seen by the spectators walking in the midst of the furnace, and singing a song of praise to God, while there was also beheld along with them a fourth person having the appearance of an angel, and whom Nabuchodonosor, on obtaining a nearer view of him, acknowledged to be the Son of God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 5:9
verses.text: Then the king having no doubt that the divine power was present in the event which had taken place, sent proclamations throughout his whole kingdom making known the miracle which had taken place, and confessing that honor was to be paid to God alone.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 5:10
verses.text: Not long after, being instructed by a vision which presented itself to him, and presently also by a voice which reached him from heaven, he is said to have done penance by laying aside his kingly power, retiring from all intercourse with mankind, and to have sustained life by herbs alone.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 5:11
verses.text: However, his empire was kept for him by the will of God, until the time was fulfilled, and at length duly acknowledging God, he was, after seven years, restored to his kingdom and former position.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 5:12
verses.text: He is related, after having conquered Sedechia (whom he carried away captive to Babylon), as we have said above, to have reigned twenty-six years, although I do not find that recorded in the sacred history.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 5:13
verses.text: But it has perhaps happened that, while I was engaged in searching out many points, I found this remark in the work of some anonymous author which had become interpolated in course of time, and in which the dates of the Babylonish kings were contained.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 5:14
verses.text: I did not think it right to pass the remark unnoticed, since it does in fact harmonize with the Chronicles, and thus its account agrees with us, to the effect that, through the succession of the kings, whose dates the record contained, it completed seventy years up to the first year of king Cyrus, and such in fact is the number of years which is stated in the sacred history to have elapsed from the captivity up to the time of Cyrus.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 6

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 6:2
verses.text: After Nabuchodonosor, the kingdom fell to his son, whom I find called Euilmarodac in the Chronicles.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 6:3
verses.text: He died in the twelfth year of his reign, and made room for his younger brother, who was called Balthasar.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 6:4
verses.text: He, when in the fourteenth year he gave a public feast to his chief men and rulers, ordered the sacred vessels (which had been taken away by Nabuchodonosor from the temple at Jerusalem, yet had not been employed for any uses of the king, but were kept laid up in the treasury) to be brought forth.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 6:5
verses.text: And when all persons, both of the male and female sex, with his wives and concubines, were using these amid the luxury and licentiousness of a royal banquet, suddenly the king observed fingers writing upon the wall, and the letters were perceived to be formed into words.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 6:6
verses.text: But no one could be found who was able to read the writing.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 6:7
verses.text: The king, therefore, in perturbation called for the magi and the Chaldaeans.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 6:8
verses.text: When these simply muttered among themselves and answered nothing, the queen reminded the king that there was a certain Hebrew, Daniel by name, who had formerly revealed to Nabuchodonosor a dream containing a secret mystery, and had then, on account of his remarkable wisdom, been promoted to the highest honors.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 6:9
verses.text: Accordingly, he, being sent for, read and interpreted the writing, to the effect that, on account of the sin of the king, who had profaned vessels sacred to God, destruction impended over him, and that his kingdom was given to the Medes and Persians.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 6:10
verses.text: And this presently took place.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 6:11
verses.text: For, on the same night, Balthasar perished, and Darius, a Mede by nation, took possession of his kingdom.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 6:12
verses.text: He again, finding that Daniel was held in the highest reputation, placed him at the head of the whole empire, in this following the judgment of the kings who had preceded him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 6:13
verses.text: For Nabuchodonosor had also set him over the kingdom, and Balthasar had presented him with a purple robe and a golden chain, while he also constituted him the third ruler in the kingdom.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 7

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 7:2
verses.text: Those, therefore, who were possessed of power along with him, stimulated by envy, because a foreigner belonging to a captive nation had been placed on a footing of equality with them, constrain the king, who had been corrupted by flattery, to enact that divine honors should be paid to him for the next thirty days, and that it should not be lawful for any one to pray to a god except the king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 7:3
verses.text: Darius was easily persuaded to that, through the folly of all kings who claim for themselves divine honors.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 7:4
verses.text: In these circumstances, Daniel being not unacquainted with what had happened, and not being ignorant that prayer ought to be addressed to God, and not to man, is accused of not having obeyed the king's commandment.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 7:5
verses.text: And much against the will of Darius, to whom he had always been dear and acceptable, the rulers prevailed that he should be let down into a den.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 7:6
verses.text: But no harm came to him when thus exposed to the wild beasts.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 7:7
verses.text: And on the king discovering this, he ordered his accusers to be given over to the lions.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 7:8
verses.text: They, however, did not pass through a similar experience, for they were instantly devoured to satisfy the hunger of the savage beasts.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 7:9
verses.text: Daniel, who had been famous before, was now esteemed still more famous; and the king, repealing his former edict, issued a new one to the effect that, all errors and superstitions being abandoned, the God of Daniel was to be worshiped.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 7:10
verses.text: There exists also a record of visions of Daniel, in which he revealed the order of events in coming ages, embracing in them also the number of the years, within which he announced that Christ would descend to earth (as has taken place), and clearly set forth the future coming of Antichrist.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 7:11
verses.text: If any one is eager to inquire into these points, he will find them more fully treated of in the book of Daniel: our design is simply to present a connected statement of events.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 7:12
verses.text: Darius is related to have reigned eighteen years; after which date Astyages began to rule over the Medes.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:2
verses.text: Him Cyrus, his grandson by his daughter, expelled from the kingdom, having used the arms of the Persians for the purpose; and hence the chief power was transferred to the Persians.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:3
verses.text: The Babylonians also fell under his power and government.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:4
verses.text: It happened at the beginning of his reign that, by the issue of public edicts, he gave permission to the Jews to return into their own country; and he also restored the sacred vessels which Nabuchodonosor had carried away from the temple at Jerusalem.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:5
verses.text: Accordingly, a few then returned into Judaea; as to the others, we have not been able to discover whether the desire of returning, or the power of doing so, was wanting.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:6
verses.text: There was at that time among the Babylonians a brazen image of Belus, a very ancient king, whom Virgil also has mentioned.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:7
verses.text: This having been deemed sacred by the superstition of the people, Cyrus also had been accustomed to worship, being deceived by the trickery of its priests.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:8
verses.text: They affirmed that the image ate and drank, while they themselves secretly carried off the daily portion which was offered to the idol.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:9
verses.text: Cyrus, then, being on intimate terms with Daniel, asked him why he did not worship the image, since it was a manifest symbol of the living God, as consuming those things which were offered to it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:10
verses.text: Daniel, laughing at the mistake of the man, replied that it could not possibly be the case, that that work of brass—mere insensate matter—could use either meat or drink.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:11
verses.text: The king, therefore, ordered the priests to be called (they were about seventy in number); and, bringing terror to bear upon them, he reprovingly asked them who was in the way of consuming what was offered, since Daniel, a man distinguished for his wisdom, maintained that that could not be done by an insensate image.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:12
verses.text: Then they, trusting in their ready-made trick, ordered the usual offering to be made, and the temple to be sealed up by the king, on the understanding that, unless on the following day the whole offering were found to have been consumed, they should suffer death, while, on the opposite being discovered, the same fate awaited Daniel.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:13
verses.text: Accordingly, the temple was sealed up by the signet of the king; but Daniel had previously, without the knowledge of the priests, covered the floor of it with ashes, so that their footprints might betray the clandestine approaches of those who entered.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:14
verses.text: The king, then, having entered the temple on the following day, perceived that those things had been taken away, which he had ordered to be served up to the idol.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:15
verses.text: Then Daniel lays open the secret fraud by the betraying footprints, showing that the priests, with their wives and children, had entered the temple by a hole opened from below, and had devoured those things which were served up to the idol.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 8:16
verses.text: Accordingly, all of them were put to death by the order of the king, while the temple and image were submitted to the power of Daniel, and were destroyed at his command.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:2
verses.text: In the meantime, those Jews, who, as we have said above, returned into their native land by the permission of Cyrus, attempted to restore their city and temple.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:3
verses.text: But, being few and poor, they made but little progress, until, at last, after the lapse of about a hundred years, while Artaxerxes the king ruled over the Persians, they were absolutely deterred from building by those who had local authority.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:4
verses.text: For, at that time, Syria and all Judaea was ruled under the empire of the Persians by magistrates and governors.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:5
verses.text: Accordingly, these took counsel to write to king Artaxerxes, that it was not fitting that opportunity should be granted to the Jews of rebuilding their city, lest, in accordance with their stubborn character, and being accustomed to rule over other nations, they should, on recovering their strength, not submit to live under the sway of a foreign power.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:6
verses.text: Thus, the plan of the rulers being approved of by the king, the building of the city was put a stop to, and delayed until the second year of Darius the king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:7
verses.text: But, who were kings of Persia throughout this period of time, we shall here insert, in order that the succession of the dates may be set forth in a regular and fixed order.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:8
verses.text: Well, then, after Darius the Mede, who, as we have said above, reigned eighteen years, Cyrus held the supreme power for thirty-one years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:9
verses.text: While making war upon the Scythians, he fell in battle, in the second year after Tarquinius Superbus began to reign at Rome.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:10
verses.text: To Cyrus succeeded his son Cambyses, and reigned eight years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:11
verses.text: He, after harassing with war Egypt and Ethiopia, and subduing these countries, returned as victor to Persia, but accidentally hurt himself, and died from that wound.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:12
verses.text: After his death, two brothers, who were magi, and Medes by nation, held rule over the Persians for seven months.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:13
verses.text: To slay these, seven of the most noble of the Persians formed a conspiracy, of whom the leader was Darius, the son of Hystaspes, who was a cousin of Cyrus, and by unanimous consent the kingdom was bestowed on him: he reigned thirty and six years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:14
verses.text: He, four years before his death, fought at Marathon, in a battle greatly celebrated both in Greek and Roman history.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:15
verses.text: That took place about the two hundred and sixtieth year after the founding of Rome, while Macerinus and Augurinus were consuls, that is, eight hundred and eighty-eight years ago, provided the research I have made into the succession of Roman consuls does not deceive me; for I have made the entire reckoning down to the time of Stilico.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:16
verses.text: After Darius came Xerxes, and he is said to have reigned twenty-one years, although I have found that the length of his rule is, in most copies, set down at twenty and five years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:17
verses.text: To him succeeded Artaxerxes, of whom we have made mention above.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:18
verses.text: Since he ordered the building of the Jewish city and temple to be stopped, the work was suspended to the second year of king Darius.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 9:19
verses.text: But that the succession of dates may be completed up to him, I have to state that Artaxerxes reigned forty-one years, Xerxes two months, and that, after him, Sucdianus ruled for seven months.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 10

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 10:2
verses.text: Next, Darius, under whom the temple was restored, obtained the kingdom, his name being at that time Ochus.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 10:3
verses.text: He had three Hebrew of tried fidelity as his bodyguard, and of these had, from the proof of his prudence which he had given, attracted towards himself the admiration of the king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 10:4
verses.text: The choice, then, being given him of asking for anything which he had formed a desire for in his heart, groaning over the ruins of his country, he begged permission to restore the city, and obtained an order from the king to urge the lieutenants and rulers to hurry forward the building of the holy temple, and furnish the expense needful to that end.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 10:5
verses.text: Accordingly, the temple was completed in four years; that is, in the sixth year after Darius began to reign, and that seemed, for the time, enough to the people of the Jews.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 10:6
verses.text: For, as it was a work of great labor to restore the city, distrusting their own resources, they did not venture at the time to begin an undertaking of so great difficulty, but were content with having rebuilt the temple.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 10:7
verses.text: At the same time, Esdras the scribe, who was skilled in the law, about twenty years after the temple had been completed (Darius being now dead who had possessed the sovereignty for nineteen years), by the permission of Artaxerxes the second (not he who had a place between the two Xerxes, but he who had succeeded to Darius Ochus), set out from Babylon with many following him, and they carried to Jerusalem the vessels of various workmanship, as well as the gifts which the king had sent for the temple of God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 10:8
verses.text: Along with them were but twelve Levites; for with difficulty that number of the tribe is related then to have been found.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 10:9
verses.text: He, having found that the Jews united in marriage with the Gentiles, rebuked them severely on that account, and ordered them to renounce all connections of that kind, as well as to put away the children which had been the issue of such marriages; and all yielded obedience to his word.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 10:10
verses.text: The people, then, being  sanctified, performed the rites sanctioned by the ancient law.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 10:11
verses.text: But I do not find that Esdras did anything with the view of restoring the city; because he thought, as I imagine, that a more urgent duty was to reform the people from the corrupt habits which they had contracted.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:2
verses.text: There was at that time at Babylon one Nehemiah, a servant of the king, a Jew by birth, and very much beloved by Artaxerxes on account of the services he had rendered.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:3
verses.text: He, having inquired of his fellow-countrymen the Jews, what was the condition of their ancestral city; and having learned that his native land remained in the same fallen condition as before, is said to have been disturbed with all his heart, and to have prayed to God with groans and many tears.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:4
verses.text: He also called to mind the sins of his nation, and urgently entreated the divine compassion.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:5
verses.text: Accordingly, the king noticing that he, while waiting at table, seemed more sorrowful than usual, asked him to explain the reasons of his grief.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:6
verses.text: Then he began to bewail the misfortunes of his nation, and the ruin of his ancestral city, which now, for almost two hundred and fifty years, being leveled with the ground, furnished a proof of the evils which had been endured, and a gazing-stock to their enemies.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:7
verses.text: He therefore begged the king to grant him the liberty of going and restoring it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:8
verses.text: The king yielded to these dutiful entreaties, and immediately sent him away with a guard of cavalry, that he might the more safely accomplish his journey, giving him, at the same time, letters to the rulers requesting them to furnish him with all that was necessary.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:9
verses.text: When he arrived at Jerusalem, he distributed the work connected with the city to the people, man by man; and all vied with each other in carrying out the orders which they received.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:10
verses.text: And already the work of rebuilding had been half accomplished, when the jealousy of the surrounding heathen burst out, and the neighboring cities conspired to interrupt the works, and to deter the Jews from building.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:11
verses.text: But Nehemiah, having stationed guards against those making assaults upon the people, was in no degree alarmed, and carried out what he had begun.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:12
verses.text: And thus, after the wall was completed, and the entrances of the gates finished, he measured out the city for the construction by families of houses within it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:13
verses.text: He reckoned, also, that the people were not adequate in numbers to the size of the city; for there were not more of them than fifty thousand of both sexes and of all ranks—to such an extent had their formerly enormous numbers been reduced by frequent wars, and by the multitude kept in captivity.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:14
verses.text: For, of old, those two tribes, of whom the remaining people were all that survived, had, when the ten tribes were separated from them, been able to furnish three hundred and twenty thousand armed men.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:15
verses.text: But being given up by God, on account of their sin, to death and captivity, they had sunk down to the miserably small number which they now presented.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:16
verses.text: This company, however, as I have said, consisted only of the two tribes: the ten which had previously been carried away being scattered among the Parthians, Medes, Indians, and Ethiopians never returned to their native country, and are to this day held under the sway of barbarous nations.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:17
verses.text: But the completion of the restored city is related to have been effected in the thirty-second year of the reign of Artaxerxes.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:18
verses.text: From that time to the crucifixion of Christ; that is, to the time when Fufius Geminus and Rubellius were consuls, there elapsed three hundred and ninety and eight years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:19
verses.text: But from the restoration of the temple to its destruction, which was completed by Titus under Vespasian, when Augustus was consul, there was a period of four hundred and eighty-three years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:20
verses.text: That was formerly predicted by Daniel, who announced that from the restoration of the temple to its overthrow there would elapse seventy and nine weeks.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 11:21
verses.text: Now, from the date of the captivity of the Jews until the time of the restoration of the city, there were two hundred and sixty years.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 12

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 12:2
verses.text: At this period of time we think Esther and Judith lived, but I confess that I cannot easily perceive with what kings especially I should connect the actions of their lives.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 12:3
verses.text: For, while Esther is said to have lived under King Artaxerxes, I find that there were two Persian kings of that name, and there is much hesitation in concluding to which of these her date is to be assigned.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 12:4
verses.text: However, it has seemed preferable to me to connect the history of Esther with that Artaxerxes under whom Jerusalem was restored, because it is not likely that, if she had lived under the former Artaxerxes, whose times Esdras has given an account of, he would have made no mention of such an illustrious woman.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 12:5
verses.text: This is all the more convincing since we know  that the building of the temple was (as we have related above) prohibited by that Artaxerxes and Esther would not have allowed that had she then been united with him in marriage.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 12:6
verses.text: But I will now repeat what things she accomplished.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 12:7
verses.text: There was at that time a certain Vastis connected with the king in marriage, a woman of marvelous beauty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 12:8
verses.text: Being accustomed to extol her loveliness to all, he one day, when he was giving a public entertainment, ordered the queen to attend for the purpose of exhibiting her beauty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 12:9
verses.text: But she, more prudent than the foolish king, and being too modest to make a show of her person before the eyes of men, refused compliance with his orders.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 12:10
verses.text: His savage mind was enraged by this insult, and he drove her forth, both from her condition of marriage with him and from the palace.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 12:11
verses.text: Consequently, when a young woman was sought after to take her place as the wife of the king, Esther was found to excel all others in beauty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 12:12
verses.text: She being a Jewess of the tribe of Benjamin, and an orphan, without father or mother, had been brought up by her cousin-german, Mardochaeus.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 12:13
verses.text: On being espoused to the king, she, by the instructions of him who had brought her up, concealed her nation and fatherland, and was also admonished by him not to become forgetful of her ancestral traditions, nor, though as a captive she had entered into marriage with a foreigner, to take part in the food of the heathen.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 12:14
verses.text: Thus, then, being united to the king, she, in a short time, as was to be expected, easily captivated his whole mind by the power of her beauty, so that, equalizing her with himself in the emblem of sovereign power, he presented her with a purple robe.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:2
verses.text: At this time, Mardochaeus was among those nearest to the king, having entirely under his charge the affairs of the household.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:3
verses.text: He had made known to the king a plot which had been formed by two eunuchs, and, on that account, had become a greater favorite, while he was presented with the highest honors.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:4
verses.text: There was at that period one Haman, a very confidential friend of the king, whom he had made equal to himself and, after the manner of sovereign rulers, had ordered to be worshiped.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:5
verses.text: Mardochaeus being the one man among all who refused to do that, had greatly kindled the wrath of the Persian against himself.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:6
verses.text: Accordingly, Haman setting his mind to work the ruin of the Hebrew, went to the king, and affirmed that there was in his kingdom a race of men of wicked superstitions, and hateful alike to God and men.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:7
verses.text: He said that, as they lived according to foreign laws, they deserved to be destroyed; and that it was a righteous thing to hand over the whole of this nation to death.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:8
verses.text: At the same time, he promised the king immense wealth out of their possessions.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:9
verses.text: The barbarous prince was easily persuaded, and an edict was issued for the slaughter of the Jews, while men were at once sent out to publish it through the whole kingdom from India even to Ethiopia.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:10
verses.text: When Mardochaeus heard of this, he rent his clothes, clothed himself in sackcloth, scattered ashes upon his head, and, going to the palace, he there made the whole place resound with his wailing and complaints, crying out that it was an unworthy thing that an innocent nation should perish, while there existed no ground for its destruction.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:11
verses.text: Esther's attention was attracted by the voice of lamentation, and she learned how the case really stood.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:12
verses.text: But she was then at a loss what step she should take (for, according to the custom of the Persians, the queen is not permitted access to the king, unless she has been sent for, and indeed is not admitted at any time the king may please, but only at a fixed period); and it happened at the time, that by this rule, Esther was held as separated from the presence of the king for the next thirty days.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:13
verses.text: However, thinking that she ought to run some risk in behalf of her fellow-countrymen, even should sure destruction await her, she was prepared to encounter death in such a noble cause, and, after having called upon God, she entered the court of the king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:14
verses.text: But the barbarian, though at first amazed at this unusual occurrence, was gradually won over by female blandishments, and at length went so far as to accompany the queen to a banquet which she had prepared.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:15
verses.text: Along with him also went Haman, the favorite of the king, but a deadly enemy of the nation of the Jews.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:16
verses.text: Well, when after the feasting the banquet began to become jovial through the many cups which were drank, Esther cast herself down at the knees of the king, and implored him to stay the destruction which threatened her nation.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:17
verses.text: Then the king promised to refuse nothing to her entreaties, if she had any further request to make.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:18
verses.text: Esther at once seized the opportunity, and demanded the death of Haman as a satisfaction to her nation, which he had desired to see destroyed.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:19
verses.text: But the king could not forget his friend, and hesitating a little, he withdrew for a short time for the purpose of considering the matter.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:20
verses.text: He then returned, and when he saw Haman grasping the knees of the queen, excited with rage, and, crying out that violence was being applied to the queen, he ordered him to be put to death.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:21
verses.text: It then came to the knowledge of the king that a cross had been got ready by Haman on which Mardochaeus was to suffer.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:22
verses.text: Thus, Haman was fixed to that very cross, and all his goods were handed over to Mardochaeus, while the Jews at large were set free.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 13:23
verses.text: Artaxerxes reigned sixty and two years, and was succeeded by Ochus.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:2
verses.text: To this series of events it will be right that I should append an account of the doings of Judith; for she is related to have lived after the captivity, but the sacred history has not revealed who was king of the Persians in her day.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:3
verses.text: It, however, calls the king under whom her exploits were performed by the name of Nabuchodonosor, and that was certainly not the one who took Jerusalem.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:4
verses.text: But I do not find that any one of that name reigned over the Persians after the captivity, unless it be that, on account of the wrath and like endeavors which he manifested, any king acting so was styled Nabuchodonosor by the Jews.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:5
verses.text: Most persons, however, think that it was Cambyses, the son of Cyrus, on this ground that he, as a conqueror, penetrated into Egypt and Ethiopia.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:6
verses.text: But the sacred history is opposed to this opinion; for Judith is described as having lived in the twelfth year of the king in question.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:7
verses.text: Now, Cambyses did not possess the supreme power for more than eight years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:8
verses.text: Wherefore, if it is allowable to make a conjecture on a point of history, I should be inclined to believe that her exploits were performed under king Ochus, who came after the second Artaxerxes.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:9
verses.text: I found this conjecture on the fact that (as I have read in profane histories) he is related to have been by nature cruel and fond of war.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:10
verses.text: For he both engaged in hostilities with his neighbors, and recovered by wars Egypt, which had revolted many years before.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:11
verses.text: At that time, also, he is related to have ridiculed the sacred rites of the Egyptians and Apis, who was regarded by them as a god; a thing which Baguas, one of his eunuchs, an Egyptian by nation, and indignant at the king's conduct, afterwards avenged by the death of the king, considering that the king had insulted the race to which he belonged.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:12
verses.text: Now, the inspired history makes mention of this Baguas; for, when Holofernes by the order of the king led an army against the Jews, it has related that Baguas was among the host.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:13
verses.text: Wherefore, not without reason may I bring it forward in proof of the opinion I have expressed that that king who was named Nabuchodonosor was really Ochus, since profane historians have related that Baguas lived in his reign.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:14
verses.text: But this ought not to be felt at all remarkable by any one, that mere worldly writers have not touched on any of those points which are recorded in the sacred writings.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:15
verses.text: The spirit of God thus took care that the history should be strictly confined within its own mysteries, unpolluted by any corrupt mouth, or that which mingled truth with fiction.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:16
verses.text: That history being, in fact, separated from the affairs of the world, and of a kind to be expressed only in sacred words, clearly ought not to have been mixed up with other histories, as being on a footing of equality with them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:17
verses.text: For it would have been most unbecoming that this history should be commingled with others treating of other things, or pursuing different inquiries.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 14:18
verses.text: But I will now proceed to what remains, and will narrate in as few words as I can the acts performed by Judith.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:2
verses.text: The Jews, then, having returned, as we have narrated above, to their native land, and the condition of their affairs and of their city being not yet properly settled, the king of the Persians made war on the Medes, and engaged in a successful battle against their king, who was named Arphaxad.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:3
verses.text: That monarch being slain, he added the nation to his empire.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:4
verses.text: He did the same to other nations, having sent before him Holofernes whom he had appointed master of his host, with a hundred and twenty thousand foot-soldiers, and twelve thousand cavalry.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:5
verses.text: He, after having ravaged in war, Cilicia and Arabia, took many cities by force, or compelled them through fear to surrender.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:6
verses.text: And now the army, having moved on to Damascus, had struck the Jews with great terror.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:7
verses.text: But as they were unable to resist, and as, at the same time, they could not bring their minds to acquiesce in the thought of surrender, since they had previously known from experience the miseries of slavery, they betook themselves in crowds to the temple.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:8
verses.text: There, with a general groaning and commingled wailing, they implored the divine assistance; saying that they had been sufficiently punished by God for their sins and offenses; and begging him to spare the remnant of them who had recently been delivered from slavery.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:9
verses.text: In the meantime, Holofernes had admitted the Moabites to surrender, and joined them to himself as allies in the war against the Jews.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:10
verses.text: He inquired of their chief men what was the power on which the Hebrews relied in not bringing their minds to submit to the thought of submission.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:11
verses.text: In reply, a certain  man called Achior stated to him the facts, viz.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:12
verses.text: : that the Jews being worshipers of God, and trained by their fathers to pious observances, had formerly passed through a period of slavery in Egypt, and that, brought out from that country by the divine aid, and having passed over on foot the sea which was dried up before them, they had at last conquered all the opposing nations, and recovered the territory inhabited by their ancestors.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:13
verses.text: That subsequently, with various fluctuations in their affairs, they had either prospered or the reverse, that, when they did sink into adversity, they had again escaped from their sufferings, finding that God was, in turn, either angry against them, or reconciled towards them, according to their deserts, so that, when they sinned, they were chastised by the attacks of enemies or by being sent into captivity, but were always unconquerable when they enjoyed the divine favor.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:14
verses.text: So then, if at the present time they are free from guilt, they cannot possibly be subdued; but if they are otherwise situated, they will easily be conquered.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:15
verses.text: Upon this, Holofernes, flushed with many victories, and thinking that everything must give way before him, was roused to wrath, because victory on his part was regarded as principally depending on the sin of the Jews, and ordered Achior to be pushed forward into the camp of the Hebrews, that he might perish in company with those who he had affirmed could not be conquered.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:16
verses.text: Now, the Jews had then made for the mountains; and those to whom the business had been assigned, proceeded to the foot of the mountains, and there left Achior in chains.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:17
verses.text: When the Jews perceived that, they freed him from his bonds and conducted him up the hill.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:18
verses.text: On their inquiring the reason of what had happened, he explained it to them, and, being received in peace, awaited the result.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:19
verses.text: I may add that, after the victory, he was circumcised and became a Jew.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:20
verses.text: Well, Holofernes, perceiving the difficulty of the localities, because he could not reach the heights, surrounded the mountains with soldiers, and took the greatest pains to cut off the Hebrews from all water supplies.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:21
verses.text: On that account, they felt all the sooner the misery of a siege.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:22
verses.text: Being therefore overcome through want of water, they went in a company to Ozias, their leader, all inclined to make a surrender.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 15:23
verses.text: But he replied that they should wait a little, and look for the divine assistance, so that the time of surrender was fixed for the fifth day afterwards.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:2
verses.text: When this became known to Judith (a widow woman of great wealth, and remarkable for beauty, but still more distinguished for her virtue than her beauty), who was then in the camp, she thought that, in the distressed circumstances of her people, some bold effort ought to be made by her, even though it should lead to her own destruction.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:3
verses.text: She therefore decks her head and beautifies her countenance, and then, attended by a single maidservant, she enters the camp of the enemy.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:4
verses.text: She was immediately conducted to Holofernes, and tells him that the affairs of her countrymen were desperate, so that she had taken precautions for her life by flight.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:5
verses.text: Then she begs of the general the right of a free egress from the camp during night, for the purpose of saying her prayers.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:6
verses.text: That order was accordingly given to the sentinels and keepers of the gates.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:7
verses.text: But when by the practice of three days she had established for herself the habit of going out and returning, and had also in this way inspired belief in her into the barbarians, the desire took possession of Holofernes of abusing the person of his captive; for, being of surpassing beauty, she had easily impressed the Persian.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:8
verses.text: Accordingly, she was conducted to the tent of the general by Baguas, the eunuch; and, commencing a banquet, the barbarian stupefied himself with a great deal of wine.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:9
verses.text: Then, when the servants withdrew, before he offered violence to the woman, he fell asleep.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:10
verses.text: Judith, seizing the opportunity, cut off the head of the enemy and carried it away with her.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:11
verses.text: Being regarded as simply going out of the camp according to her usual custom, she returned to her own people in safety.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:12
verses.text: On the following day the Hebrews held forth for show the head of Holofernes from the heights; and, making a sally, marched upon the camp of the enemy.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:13
verses.text: And then the barbarians assemble in crowds at the tent of their general, waiting for the signal of battle.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:14
verses.text: When his mutilated body was discovered, they turned to flight under the influence of a disgraceful panic, and fled before the enemy.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:15
verses.text: The Jews, for their part, pursued the fugitives, and after slaying many thousands, took possession of the camp and the booty within it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:16
verses.text: Judith was extolled with the loftiest praises, and is said to have lived one hundred and five years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:17
verses.text: If these things took place, as we believe, under king Ochus, in the twelfth year of his reign, then from the date of the restoration of Jerusalem up to that war there elapsed two and twenty years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:18
verses.text: Now Ochus reigned in all twenty-three years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:19
verses.text: And he was beyond all others cruel, and more than of a barbarous disposition.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:20
verses.text: Baguas, the eunuch, took him off by poison on an occasion of his suffering from illness.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 16:21
verses.text: After him, Arses his son held the government for three years, and Darius for four.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 17

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 17:2
verses.text: Against him Alexander of Macedon engaged in war.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 17:3
verses.text: And on his being conquered, the sovereign power was taken from the Persians, after having lasted, from the time of its establishment by Cyrus, two hundred and fifty years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 17:4
verses.text: Alexander, the conqueror of almost all nations, is said to have visited the temple at Jerusalem, and to have conveyed gifts into it; and he proclaimed throughout the whole territory which he had reduced under his sway that it should be free to the Jews living in it to return to their own country.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 17:5
verses.text: At the end of the twelfth year of his reign, and seven years after he had conquered Darius, he died at Babylon.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 17:6
verses.text: His friends who, along with him, had carried on those very important wars, divided his empire among themselves.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 17:7
verses.text: For some time they administered the charges they had undertaken without making use of the name of king, while a certain Arridaeus Philippus, the brother of Alexander, reigned, to whom, being of a very weak character, the sovereignty was nominally and in appearance given, but the real power was in the hands of those who had divided among themselves the army and the provinces.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 17:8
verses.text: And indeed this state of things did not long continue, but all preferred that they should be called by the name of kings.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 17:9
verses.text: In Syria Seleucus was the first king after Alexander, Persia and Babylon being also subject to his sway.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 17:10
verses.text: At that time the Jews paid an annual tribute of three hundred talents of silver to the king; but they were governed not by foreign magistrates but by their own priests.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 17:11
verses.text: And they lived according to the fashions of their ancestors until very many of them again corrupted by a long peace, began to mingle all things with seditions, and to create disturbances, while they aimed at the high-priesthood under the influence of lust, avarice, and the desire of power.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 18

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 18:2
verses.text: For, first of all, under king Seleucus, the son of Antiochus the great, a certain man called Simon accused to the king on false charges Onias the priest, a holy and uncorrupted man, and thus tried, but in vain, to overthrow him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 18:3
verses.text: Then, after an interval of time, Jason, the brother of Onias, went to Antiochus the king, who had succeeded his brother Seleucus, and promised him an increase of tribute, if the high-priesthood were transferred to him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 18:4
verses.text: And although it was an unusual, and indeed, until now, an unpermitted thing for a man to enjoy the high-priesthood year after year, still the eager mind of the king, diseased with avarice, was easily persuaded.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 18:5
verses.text: Accordingly, Onias was driven from office, and the priesthood bestowed on Jason.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 18:6
verses.text: He harassed his countrymen and his country in the most shameful manner.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 18:7
verses.text: Then, as he had sent through a certain Menelaus (the brother of that Simon who has been mentioned) the money he had promised to the king, a way being once laid open to his ambition, Menelaus obtained the priesthood by the same arts which Jason had employed before.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 18:8
verses.text: But not long after, as he had not furnished the promised amount of money, he was driven from his position, and Lysimachus substituted in his stead.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 18:9
verses.text: Then there arose disgraceful conflicts between Jason and Menelaus, until Jason, as an exile, left the country.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 18:10
verses.text: By examples like these, the morals of the people became corrupted to such an extent, that numbers of the natives begged permission from Antiochus to live after the fashion of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 18:11
verses.text: And when the king granted their request, all the most worthless vied with each other in their endeavors to construct temples, to sacrifice to idols, and to profane the law.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 18:12
verses.text: In the meantime, Antiochus returned from Alexandria (for he had then made war upon the king of Egypt, which, however, he gave up by the orders of the senate and Roman people, when Paulus and Crassus were consuls), and went to Jerusalem.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 18:13
verses.text: Finding the people at variance from the diverse superstitions they had adopted, he destroyed the law of God, and showed favor to those who followed impious courses, while he carried off all the ornaments of the temple, and wasted it with much destruction.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 18:14
verses.text: That came to pass in the hundred and fiftieth year after the death of Alexander, Paulus and Crassus being, as we have said, consuls, about five years after Antiochus began to reign.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:2
verses.text: But that the order of the dates may be correctly preserved, and that it may appear more clearly who this Antiochus was, we shall enumerate both the names and times of the kings who came after Alexander in Syria.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:3
verses.text: Well, then, king Alexander having died, as we have related above, his whole empire was portioned out by his friends, and was governed for some time by them under the name of the king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:4
verses.text: Seleucus, after the lapse of nine years, was himself styled king in Syria, and reigned thirty-two years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:5
verses.text: After him came Antiochus, his son, with a reign of twenty-one years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:6
verses.text: Then came Antiochus, the son of Antiochus, who was surnamed Theus, and he reigned fifteen years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:7
verses.text: After him, his son  Seleucus, surnamed Callinicus, reigned twenty-one years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:8
verses.text: Another Seleucus, the son of Callinicus, reigned three years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:9
verses.text: After his death Antiochus, the brother of Callinicus, held Asia and Syria for thirty-seven years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:10
verses.text: This is the Antiochus against whom Lucius Scipio Asiaticus made war; and he, being worsted in the war was stripped of a part of his empire.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:11
verses.text: He had two sons, Seleucus and Antiochus, the latter of whom he had given as a hostage to the Romans.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:12
verses.text: Thus, then, Antiochus the great having died, his younger son Seleucus obtained the kingdom, under whom, as we have said, Onias the priest had an accusation brought against him by Simon.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:13
verses.text: Then Antiochus was set free by the Romans, and there was given in his place as hostage Demetrius, the son of Seleucus, who was at that time reigning.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:14
verses.text: Seleucus dying in the twelfth year of his reign, his brother Antiochus, who had been a hostage at Rome, seized the kingdom.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:15
verses.text: He, five years after the beginning of his reign, did, as we have shown above, lay waste Jerusalem.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:16
verses.text: For, as he had to pay a heavy tribute to the Romans, he was almost of necessity compelled, in order to meet that enormous expense, to provide himself with money by rapine, and to neglect no opportunity of plundering.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:17
verses.text: Then, after two years, the Jews being again visited by a similar disaster to that which they had suffered before, lest it should happen that, driven on by their numerous miseries, they should commence war, he placed a garrison in the citadel.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:18
verses.text: Next, with the view of overturning the holy law, he published an edict, that all, forsaking the traditions of their ancestors, should live after the manner of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:19
verses.text: And there were not wanting those who readily obeyed this profane enactment.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 19:20
verses.text: Then truly there was a horrible spectacle presented; through all the cities sacrifices were publicly offered in the streets, while the sacred volumes of the law and the prophets were consumed with fire.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 20

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 20:2
verses.text: At that time, Matthathias, the son of John, was high-priest.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 20:3
verses.text: When he was being forced by the servants of the king to obey the edict, with marvelous courage he set at naught the profane enactments, and slew, in the presence of all, a Hebrew who was publicly performing profane acts.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 20:4
verses.text: A leader having thus been found, rebellion at once took place.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 20:5
verses.text: Matthathias left the town; and as many flocked to him, he got up the appearance of a regular army.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 20:6
verses.text: The object of every man in that host was to defend himself by arms against a profane government, and rather even to fall in war than to take part in impious ceremonies.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 20:7
verses.text: In the meantime, Antiochus was compelling those Jews who were found in the Greek cities in his dominions to offer sacrifice, and was visiting with unheard-of torments those who refused.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 20:8
verses.text: At this time, there occurred that well-known and remarkable suffering of the seven brothers and their mother.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 20:9
verses.text: All of the brothers, when they were being forced to violate the law of God, and the customs of their ancestors, preferred rather to die.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 20:10
verses.text: At last, their mother, too, accompanied them both in their sufferings and death.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:2
verses.text: In the meantime, Matthathias dies, having appointed in his own place his son Judah, as general of the army which he had brought together.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:3
verses.text: Under his leadership, several successful battles took place against the royal forces.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:4
verses.text: For first of all, he destroyed, along with his whole army, Apollonius, the enemy's general, who had entered on the conflict with a large number of troops.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:5
verses.text: When a certain man, named Seron, who was then the ruler of Syria, heard of this, he increased his forces, and attacked Judah with much spirit as being superior in numbers, but when a battle took place, he was routed and put to flight; and with the loss of nearly eight hundred men, he returned to Syria.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:6
verses.text: On this becoming known to Antiochus, he was filled with rage and regret, inasmuch as it vexed him that his generals had been conquered, notwithstanding their large armies.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:7
verses.text: He therefore gathers aid from his whole empire, and bestows a donative on the soldiers, almost to the exhaustion of his treasury.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:8
verses.text: For he was then suffering in a very special manner from the want of money.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:9
verses.text: The reason of this was, on the one side, that the Jews, who had been accustomed to pay him an annual tribute of more than three hundred talents of silver, were now in a state of rebellion against him; and on the other side, that many of the Greek cities and countries were unsettled by the evil of persecution.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:10
verses.text: For Antiochus had not spared even the Gentiles, whom he had sought to persuade to abandon their long-established superstitions, and to draw over to one kind of religious observance.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:11
