verses.text: And no doubt, those of them who regarded nothing as sacred, easily were induced to give up their ancient forms of worship, but at the same time all were in a state of alarm and disaster.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:12
verses.text: For these reasons, then, the taxes had ceased to be paid.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:13
verses.text: Boiling with wrath on these grounds (for he who had of old been the richest of kings now deeply felt the poverty due to his own wickedness), he divided his forces with Lysias, and committed to him Syria and the war against the Jews, while he himself set out against the Persians, to collect the taxes among them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:14
verses.text: Lysias, then, selected Ptolemy, Gorgias, Doro, and Nicanor, as generals in the war; and to these he gave forty thousand infantry, and seven thousand cavalry.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:15
verses.text: At the first onset these caused great alarm among the Jews.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:16
verses.text: Then Judah, when all were in despair, exhorted his men to go with courageous hearts to battle—that, if they put their trust in God, everything would give way before them; for that often before then the victory had been won by a few fighting against many.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:17
verses.text: A fast was proclaimed, and sacrifice was offered, after which they went down to battle.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:18
verses.text: The result was that the forces of the enemy were scattered, and Judah, taking possession of their camp, found in it both much gold and Tyrian treasures.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:19
verses.text: For merchants from Syria, having no doubt as to victory, had followed the king's army with the hope of purchasing prisoners, and now were themselves spoiled.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 21:20
verses.text: When these things were reported to Lysias by messengers, he got together troops with still greater efforts, and in a year after again attacked the Jews with an enormous army; but being defeated, he retreated to Antioch.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 22

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 22:2
verses.text: Judah, on the defeat of the enemy, returned to Jerusalem, and bent his mind on the purification and restoration of the temple, which having been overthrown by Antiochus, and profaned by the Gentiles, presented a melancholy spectacle.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 22:3
verses.text: But as the Syrians held the citadel, which being connected with the temple, but standing above it in position, was really impregnable, the lower parts proved inaccessible, as frequent sallies from above prevented persons from approaching them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 22:4
verses.text: But Judah placed against these assailants a very powerful body of his men.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 22:5
verses.text: Thus the work of the sacred building was protected, and the temple was surrounded with a wall, while armed men were appointed to maintain a perpetual defence.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 22:6
verses.text: And Lysias, having again returned into Judaea with increased forces, was once more defeated with a great loss both of his own army and of the auxiliaries, which being sent to him by various states had combined with him in the war.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 22:7
verses.text: In the meantime, Antiochus, who, as we have said above, had marched into Persia, endeavored to plunder the town of Elymus, the wealthiest in the country, and a temple situated there which was filled with gold; but, as a multitude flocked together from all sides for the defense of the place, he was put to flight.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 22:8
verses.text: Moreover, he received news of the want of success which had attended the efforts of Lysias.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 22:9
verses.text: Thus, from distress of mind, he fell into bodily disease.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 22:10
verses.text: But as he was then tormented with internal sufferings, he remembered the miseries which he had inflicted on the people of God, and acknowledged that these evils had deservedly been sent upon him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 22:11
verses.text: Then, after a few days, he died, having reigned eleven years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 22:12
verses.text: He left the kingdom to his son Antiochus, to whom the name of Eupator was given.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:2
verses.text: At that time Judah besieged the Syrians who were posted in the citadel.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:3
verses.text: They, being sore pressed with famine and want of all things, sent messengers to the king to implore assistance.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:4
verses.text: Accordingly, Eupator came to their aid with a hundred thousand infantry and twenty thousand cavalry, while elephants marched in front of his line, causing immense terror to the onlookers.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:5
verses.text: Then Judah, abandoning the siege, went to meet the king, and routed the Syrians in the first battle.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:6
verses.text: The king begged for peace, which, because he, with his treacherous disposition, made a bad use of, vengeance followed his treachery.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:7
verses.text: For Demetrius, the son of Seleucus, who, we have said above, was handed over as a hostage to the Romans, when he heard that Antiochus had departed, begged that they would send him to take possession of the kingdom.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:8
verses.text: And when this was refused to him, he secretly fled from Rome, came into Syria, and seized the supreme power, having slain the son of Antiochus, who had reigned one year and six months.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:9
verses.text: It was during his reign that the Jews first begged the friendship of the Roman people, and alliance with them; and the embassy to this effect having been kindly received, they were, by a decree of the senate, styled allies and friends.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:10
verses.text: In the meantime Demetrius was, by means of his generals, carrying on war against Judah.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:11
verses.text: And first the army was led by a certain man named Bacchides, and by Alcimus, a Jew; Nicanor, being afterwards placed at the head of the war, fell in battle.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:12
verses.text: Then Bacchides and Alcimus, recovering power, and having increased their forces, fought against Judah.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:13
verses.text: The Syrians, turning out victorious in that battle, cruelly abused their victory.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:14
verses.text: The Hebrews elect Jonathan, the brother of Judah, in his place.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:15
verses.text: In the meantime, Alcimus, after he had fearfully desolated Jerusalem, dies; Bacchides, being thus deprived of his ally, returns to the king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:16
verses.text: Then, after an interval of two years, Bacchides again made war upon the Jews, and being beaten, he  begged for peace.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 23:17
verses.text: This was granted him certain conditions, to the effect that he should give up the deserters and prisoners, along with all that he had taken in war.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 24

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 24:2
verses.text: While these things are going on in Judaea, a certain young man educated at Rhodes, by name Alexander, gave himself out as being the son of Antiochus (which was false), and assisted by the power of Ptolemy, king of Alexandria, came into Syria with an army.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 24:3
verses.text: He conquered Demetrius in war, and slew him after he had reigned twelve years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 24:4
verses.text: This Alexander before he made war against Demetrius, had formed an alliance with Jonathan, and had presented him with a purple robe and royal ensigns.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 24:5
verses.text: For this reason Jonathan had assisted him with auxiliary forces; and on the defeat of Demetrius, had been the very first to meet him with congratulations.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 24:6
verses.text: Nor did Alexander afterwards violate the faith which he had pledged.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 24:7
verses.text: Accordingly, in the five years during which he held the chief power, the affairs of the Jews were peaceful.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 24:8
verses.text: In these circumstances, Demetrius, the son of Demetrius, who, after the death of his father, had betaken himself to Crete, at the instigation of Lasthenes, general of the Cretans, tried by war to recover the kingdom of his, father, but finding his power unequal to the task, he implored Ptolemy Philometor, king of Egypt, the father-in-law of Alexander, but who was then on bad terms with his son-in-law, to give him assistance.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 24:9
verses.text: But he, induced not so much by the entreaties of the suppliant as by the hope of seizing Syria, joined his forces with those of Demetrius, and gives him his daughter, who had been married to Alexander.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 24:10
verses.text: Against these two Alexander fought a pitched battle.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 24:11
verses.text: Ptolemy fell in the fight, but Alexander was defeated; and he was soon afterwards slain, after he had reigned five, or as I find it stated in many authors, nine years.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 25

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 25:2
verses.text: Demetrius, having thus obtained the kingdom, treated Jonathan with kindness, made a treaty with him, and restored the Jews to their own laws.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 25:3
verses.text: In the meantime, Tryphon, who had belonged to the party of Alexander, was appointed governor of Syria, to keep him in check by war.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 25:4
verses.text: Jonathan, on the other hand, descended to battle, formidable with an army of forty thousand men.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 25:5
verses.text: Tryphon, when he saw himself unequal to the contest, pretended a desire for peace, and slew Ptolemais who had been received and invited into friendship with him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 25:6
verses.text: After Jonathan, the chief power was conferred on his brother Simon.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 25:7
verses.text: He celebrated the funeral of his brother with great pomp, and built those well-known seven pyramids of most noble workmanship, in which he buried the remains both of his brothers and of his father.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 25:8
verses.text: Then Demetrius renewed his treaty with the Jews; and in consideration of the loss caused to them by Tryphon (for after the death of Jonathan he had wasted by war their cities and territories), he remitted to them their annual tribute forever; for up to that time, they had paid tribute to the kings of Syria, except when they resisted by force of arms.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 25:9
verses.text: That took place in the second year of king Demetrius; and we have noted that, because up to this year we have run through the times of the Asiatic kings, that the series of dates being given in order might be perfectly clear.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 25:10
verses.text: But now we shall arrange the order of events through the times of those, who were either high-priests or kings among the Jews, up to the period of the birth of Christ.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:2
verses.text: Well, then, after Jonathan, his brother Simon, as has been said above, ruled over the Hebrews with the power of high-priest.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:3
verses.text: For that honor was then bestowed upon him both by his own countrymen and by the Roman people.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:4
verses.text: He began to rule over his countrymen in the second year of king Demetrius, but eight years afterwards, being deceived by a plot of Ptolemy, he met his death.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:5
verses.text: He was succeeded by his son John.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:6
verses.text: And he, on the ground that he had fought with distinction against the Hyrcani, a very powerful nation, received the surname of Hyrcanus.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:7
verses.text: He died, after having held the supreme power for twenty-six years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:8
verses.text: After him, Aristobulus being appointed high-priest, was the first of all living after the captivity to assume the name of king, and to have a crown placed upon his head.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:9
verses.text: At the close of a year, he died.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:10
verses.text: Then Alexander, his son, who was both king and high-priest, reigned twenty-seven years; but I have found nothing in his doings worthy of mention, except his cruelty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:11
verses.text: He having left two young sons named Aristobulus and Hyrcanus, Salina or Alexandra, his wife, held the sovereignty for three years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:12
verses.text: After his decease, frightful conflicts about the supreme power arose between the two brothers.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:13
verses.text: And first of all, Hyrcanus held the government; but being by and by defeated by his brother Aristobulus, he  fled to Pompey.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:14
verses.text: That Roman general, having finished the war with Mithridates, and settled Armenia and Pontus, being, in fact, the conqueror of all the nations which he had visited, desired to march inwards, and to add all the neighboring regions to the Roman empire.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:15
verses.text: He therefore inquired into the causes of the war, and the means of obtaining the mastery.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:16
verses.text: Accordingly he readily received Hyrcanus, and, under his guidance, attacked the Jews; but when the city was taken and destroyed, he spared the temple.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:17
verses.text: He sent Aristobulus in chains to Rome, and restored the right of the high-priesthood to Hyrcanus.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:18
verses.text: Settling the tribute to be paid by the Jews, he placed over them as governor a certain Antipater of Askelon.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 26:19
verses.text: Hyrcanus held the chief power for thirty-four years; but while he carried on war against the Parthians, he was taken prisoner.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 27

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 27:2
verses.text: Then Herod, a foreigner, the son of Antipater of Askelon, asked and received the sovereignty of Judaea from the senate and people of Rome.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 27:3
verses.text: Under him, the Jews began for the first time to have a foreigner as king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 27:4
verses.text: For as now the advent of Christ was at hand, it was necessary, according to the predictions of the prophets, that they should be deprived of their own rulers, that they might not look for anything beyond Christ.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 27:5
verses.text: Under this Herod, in the thirty-third year of his reign, Christ was born on the twenty-fifth of December in the consulship of Sabinus and Rufinus.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 27:6
verses.text: But we do not venture to touch on these things which are contained in the Gospels, and subsequently in the Acts of the Apostles, lest the character of our condensed work should, in any measure, detract from the dignity of the events; and I shall proceed to what remains.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 27:7
verses.text: Herod reigned four years after the birth of the Lord; for the whole period of his reign comprised thirty-seven years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 27:8
verses.text: After him, came Archelaus the tetrarch, for eight years, and Herod for twenty-four years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 27:9
verses.text: Under him, in the eighteenth year of his reign, the Lord was crucified, Fufius Geminus and Rubellius Geminus being consuls; from which date up to the consulship of Stilico, there have elapsed three hundred and seventy-two years.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 28

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 28:2
verses.text: Luke made known the doings of the apostles up to the time when Paul was brought to Rome under the emperor Nero.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 28:3
verses.text: As to Nero, I shall not say that he was the worst of kings, but that he was worthily held the basest of all men, and even of wild beasts.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 28:4
verses.text: It was he who first began a persecution; and I am not sure but he will be the last also to carry it on, if, indeed, we admit, as many are inclined to believe, that he will yet appear immediately before the coming of Antichrist.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 28:5
verses.text: Our subject would induce me to set forth his vices at some length, if it were not inconsistent with the purpose of this work to enter upon so vast a topic.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 28:6
verses.text: I content myself with the remark, that he showed himself in every way most abominable and cruel, and at length even went so far as to be the murderer of his own mother.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 28:7
verses.text: After this, he also married a certain Pythagoras in the style of solemn alliances, the bridal veil being put upon the emperor, while the usual dowry, and the marriage couch, and wedding torches, and, in short, all the other observances were forthcoming—things which even in the case of women, are not looked upon without some feeling of modesty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 28:8
verses.text: But as to his other actions, I doubt whether the description of them would excite greater shame or sorrow.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 28:9
verses.text: He first attempted to abolish the name of Christian, in accordance with the fact that vices are always inimical to virtues, and that all good men are ever regarded by the wicked as casting reproach upon them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 28:10
verses.text: For, at that time, our divine religion had obtained a wide prevalence in the city.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 28:11
verses.text: Peter was there executing the office of bishop, and Paul, too, after he had been brought to Rome, on appealing to Caesar from the unjust judgment of the governor.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 28:12
verses.text: Multitudes then came together to hear Paul, and these, influenced by the truth which they were given to know, and by the miracles of the apostles, which they then so frequently performed, turned to the worship of God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 28:13
verses.text: For then took place the well-known and celebrated encounter of Peter and Paul with Simon.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 28:14
verses.text: He, after he had flown up into the air by his magical arts, and supported by two demons (with the view of proving that he was a god), the demons being put to flight by the prayers of the apostles, fell to the earth in the sight of all the people, and was dashed to pieces.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 29

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 29:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIX.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 29:2
verses.text: In the meantime, the number of the Christians being now very large, it happened that Rome was destroyed by fire, while Nero was stationed at Antium.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 29:3
verses.text: But the opinion of all cast the odium of causing the fire upon the emperor, and he was believed in this way to have sought for the glory of building a new city.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 29:4
verses.text: And in fact, Nero could not by any means he tried  escape from the charge that the fire had been caused by his orders.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 29:5
verses.text: He therefore turned the accusation against the Christians, and the most cruel tortures were accordingly inflicted upon the innocent.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 29:6
verses.text: Nay, even new kinds of death were invented, so that, being covered in the skins of wild beasts, they perished by being devoured by dogs, while many were crucified or slain by fire, and not a few were set apart for this purpose, that, when the day came to a close, they should be consumed to serve for light during the night.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 29:7
verses.text: In this way, cruelty first began to be manifested against the Christians.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 29:8
verses.text: Afterwards, too, their religion was prohibited by laws which were enacted; and by edicts openly set forth it was proclaimed unlawful to be a Christian.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 29:9
verses.text: At that time Paul and Peter were condemned to death, the former being beheaded with a sword, while Peter suffered crucifixion.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 29:10
verses.text: And while these things went on at Rome, the Jews, not able to endure the injuries they suffered under the rule of Festus Florus, began to rebel.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 29:11
verses.text: Vespasian, being sent by Nero against them, with proconsular power, defeated them in numerous important battles, and compelled them to flee within the walls of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 29:12
verses.text: In the meanwhile Nero, now hateful even to himself from a consciousness of his crimes, disappears from among men, leaving it uncertain whether or not he had laid violent hands upon himself: certainly his body was never found.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 29:13
verses.text: It was accordingly believed that, even if he did put an end to himself with a sword, his wound was cured, and his life preserved, according to that which was written regarding him,—"And his mortal wound was healed,"—to be sent forth again near the end of the world, in order that he may practice the mystery of iniquity.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:1
verses.text: Chapter XXX.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:2
verses.text: So then, after the departure of Nero, Galba seized the government; and ere long, on Galba being slain, Otho secured it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:3
verses.text: Then Vitellius from Gaul, trusting to the armies which he commanded, entered the city, and having killed Otho, assumed the sovereignty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:4
verses.text: This afterwards passed to Vespasian, and although that was accomplished by evil means, yet it had the good effect of rescuing the state from the hands of the wicked.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:5
verses.text: While Vespasian was besieging Jerusalem, he took possession of the imperial power; and as the fashion is, he was saluted as emperor by the army, with a diadem placed upon his head.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:6
verses.text: He made his son Titus, Caesar; and assigned him a portion of the forces, along with the task of continuing the siege of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:7
verses.text: Vespasian set out for Rome, and was received with the greatest favor by the senate and people; and Vitellius having killed himself, his hold of the sovereign power was fully confirmed.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:8
verses.text: The Jews, meanwhile, being closely besieged, as no chance either of peace or surrender was allowed them, were at length perishing from famine, and the streets began everywhere to be filled with dead bodies, for the duty of burying them could no longer be performed.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:9
verses.text: Moreover, they ventured on eating all things of the most abominable nature, and did not even abstain from human bodies, except those which putrefaction had already laid hold of and thus excluded from use as food.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:10
verses.text: The Romans, accordingly, rushed in upon the exhausted defenders of the city.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:11
verses.text: And it so happened that the whole multitude from the country, and from other towns of Judaea, had then assembled for the day of the Passover: doubtless, because it pleased God that the impious race should be given over to destruction at the very time of the year at which they had crucified the Lord.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:12
verses.text: The Pharisees for a time maintained their ground most boldly in defense of the temple, and at length, with minds obstinately bent on death, they, of their own accord, committed themselves to the flames.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:13
verses.text: The number of those who suffered death is related to have been eleven hundred thousand, and one hundred thousand were taken captive and sold.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:14
verses.text: Titus is said, after calling a council, to have first deliberated whether he should destroy the temple, a structure of such extraordinary work.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:15
verses.text: For it seemed good to some that a sacred edifice, distinguished above all human achievements, ought not to be destroyed, inasmuch as, if preserved, it would furnish an evidence of Roman moderation, but, if destroyed, would serve for a perpetual proof of Roman cruelty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:16
verses.text: But on the opposite side, others and Titus himself thought that the temple ought specially to be overthrown, in order that the religion of the Jews and of the Christians might more thoroughly be subverted; for that these religions, although contrary to each other, had nevertheless proceeded from the same authors; that the Christians had sprung up from among the Jews; and that, if the root were extirpated, the offshoot would speedily perish.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:17
verses.text: Thus, according to the divine will, the minds of all being inflamed, the temple was destroyed, three hundred and thirty-one years ago.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:18
verses.text: And this last overthrow of the temple, and final captivity of the Jews, by which, being exiles from their native land, they are beheld scattered through the whole world, furnish a daily demonstration to the world, that they have been punished on no other account than for the impious hands which they laid upon Christ.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 30:19
verses.text: For though on other occasions they were often given over to captivity  on account of their sins, yet they never paid the penalty of slavery beyond a period of seventy years.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 31

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 31:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 31:2
verses.text: Then, after an interval, Domitian, the son of Vespasian, persecuted the Christians.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 31:3
verses.text: At this date, he banished John the Apostle and Evangelist to the island of Patmos.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 31:4
verses.text: There he, secret mysteries having been revealed to him, wrote and published his book of the holy Revelation, which indeed is either foolishly or impiously not accepted by many.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 31:5
verses.text: And with no great interval there then occurred the third persecution under Trajan.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 31:6
verses.text: But he, when after torture and racking he found nothing in the Christians worthy of death or punishment, forbade any further cruelty to be put forth against them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 31:7
verses.text: Then under Adrian the Jews attempted to rebel, and endeavored to plunder both Syria and Palestine; but on an army being sent against them, they were subdued.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 31:8
verses.text: At this time Adrian, thinking that he would destroy the Christian faith by inflicting an injury upon the place, set up the images of demons both in the temple and in the place where the Lord suffered.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 31:9
verses.text: And because the Christians were thought principally to consist of Jews (for the church at Jerusalem did not then have a priest except of the circumcision), he ordered a cohort of soldiers to keep constant guard in order to prevent all Jews from approaching to Jerusalem.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 31:10
verses.text: This, however, rather benefited the Christian faith, because almost all then believed in Christ as God while continuing in the observance of the law.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 31:11
verses.text: Undoubtedly that was arranged by the over-ruling care of the Lord, in order that the slavery of the law might be taken away from the liberty of the faith and of the church.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 31:12
verses.text: In this way, Mark from among the Gentiles was then, first of all, bishop at Jerusalem.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 31:13
verses.text: A fourth persecution is reckoned as having taken place under Adrian, which, however, he afterwards forbade to be carried on, declaring it to be unjust that any one should be put on his trial without a charge being specified against him.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 32

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 32:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 32:2
verses.text: After Adrian, the churches had peace under the rule of Antoninus Pius.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 32:3
verses.text: Then the fifth persecution began under Aurelius, the son of Antoninus.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 32:4
verses.text: And then, for the first time, martyrdoms were seen taking place in Gaul, for the religion of God had been accepted somewhat late beyond the Alps.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 32:5
verses.text: Then the sixth persecution of the Christians took place under the emperor Severus.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 32:6
verses.text: At this time Leonida, the father of Origen, poured forth his sacred blood in martyrdom.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 32:7
verses.text: Then, during an interval of thirty-eight years, the Christians enjoyed peace, except that at the middle of that time Maximinus persecuted the clerics of some churches.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 32:8
verses.text: Ere long, under Decius as emperor, the seventh bloody persecution broke out against the Christians.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 32:9
verses.text: Next, Valerian proved himself the eighth enemy of the saints.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 32:10
verses.text: After him, with an interval of about fifty years, there arose, under the emperors Diocletian and Maximian, a most bitter persecution which, for ten continuous years, wasted the people of God.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 32:11
verses.text: At this period, almost the whole world was stained with the sacred blood of the martyrs.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 32:12
verses.text: In fact, they vied with each other in rushing upon these glorious struggles, and martyrdom by glorious deaths was then much more keenly sought after than bishoprics are now attempted to be got by wicked ambition.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 32:13
verses.text: Never more than at that time was the world exhausted by wars, nor did we ever achieve victory with a greater triumph than when we showed that we could not be conquered by the slaughters of ten long years.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 32:14
verses.text: There survive also accounts of the sufferings of the martyrs at that time which were committed to writing; but I do not think it suitable to subjoin these lest I should exceed the limits prescribed to this work.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 33

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 33:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 33:2
verses.text: Well, the end of the persecutions was reached eighty-eight years ago, at which date the emperors began to be Christians.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 33:3
verses.text: For Constantine then obtained the sovereignty, and he was the first Christian of all the Roman rulers.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 33:4
verses.text: At that time, it is true, Licinius, who was a rival of Constantine for the empire, had commanded his soldiers to sacrifice, and was expelling from the service those who refused to do so.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 33:5
verses.text: But that is not reckoned among the persecutions; it was an affair of too little moment to be able to inflict any wound upon the churches.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 33:6
verses.text: From that time, we have continued to enjoy tranquillity; nor do I believe that there will be any further persecutions, except that which Antichrist will carry on just before the end of the world.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 33:7
verses.text: For it has been proclaimed in divine words, that the world was to be visited by ten afflictions; and since nine of these have already been endured, the one which remains must be  the last.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 33:8
verses.text: During this period of time, it is marvelous how the Christian religion has prevailed.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 33:9
verses.text: For Jerusalem which had presented a horrible mass of ruins was then adorned with most numerous and magnificent churches.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 33:10
verses.text: And Helena, the mother of the emperor Constantine (who reigned along with her son as Augusta), having a strong desire to behold Jerusalem, cast down the idols and the temples which were found there; and in course of time, through the exercise of her royal powers, she erected churches on the site of the Lord's passion, resurrection, and ascension.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 33:11
verses.text: It is a remarkable fact that the spot on which the divine footprints had last been left when the Lord was carried up in a cloud to heaven, could not be joined by a pavement with the remaining part of the street.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 33:12
verses.text: For the earth, unaccustomed to mere human contact, rejected all the appliances laid upon it, and often threw back the blocks of marble in the faces of those who were seeking to place them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 33:13
verses.text: Moreover, it is an enduring proof of the soil of that place having been trodden by God, that the footprints are still to be seen; and although the faith of those who daily flock to that place, leads them to vie with each other in seeking to carry away what had been trodden by the feet of the Lord, yet the sand of the place suffers no injury; and the earth still preserves the same appearance which it presented of old, as if it had been sealed by the footprints impressed upon it.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 34

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 34:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 34:2
verses.text: Through the kind efforts of the same queen, the cross of the Lord was then found.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 34:3
verses.text: It could not, of course, be consecrated at the beginning, owing to the opposition of the Jews, and afterwards it had been covered over by the rubbish of the ruined city.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 34:4
verses.text: And now, it would never have been revealed except to one seeking for it in such a believing spirit.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 34:5
verses.text: Accordingly, Helena having first got information about the place of our Lord's passion, caused a band of soldiers to be brought to it, while the whole multitude of the inhabitants of the locality vied with each other in seeking to gratify the desires of the queen, and ordered the earth to be dug up, and all the adjacent most extensive ruins to be cleared out.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 34:6
verses.text: Ere long, as the reward of her faith and labor, three crosses (as of old they had been fixed for the Lord and the two robbers) were discovered.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 34:7
verses.text: But upon this, the greater difficulty of distinguishing the gibbet on which the Lord had hung, disturbed the minds and thoughts of all, lest by a mistake, likely enough to be committed by mere mortals, they might perhaps consecrate as the cross of the Lord, that which belonged to one of the robbers.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 34:8
verses.text: They form then the plan of placing one who had recently died in contact with the crosses.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 34:9
verses.text: Nor is there any delay in carrying out this purpose; for just as if by the appointment of God, the funeral of a dead man was then being conducted with the usual ceremonies, and all rushing up took the body from the bier.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 34:10
verses.text: It was applied in vain to the first two crosses, but when it touched that of Christ, wonderful to tell, while all stood trembling, the dead body was shaken off, and stood up in the midst of those looking at it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 34:11
verses.text: The cross was thus discovered, and was consecrated with all due ceremony.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 35

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 35:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 35:2
verses.text: Such were the things accomplished by Helena, while, under a Christian prince, the world had both attained to liberty, and possessed in him an exemplar of faith.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 35:3
verses.text: But a far more dreadful danger than all that had preceded fell upon all the churches from that state of tranquillity.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 35:4
verses.text: For then the Arian heresy burst forth, and disturbed the whole world by the error which it instilled.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 35:5
verses.text: For by means of the two Ariuses, who were the most active originators of this unfaithfulness, the emperor himself was led astray; and while he seemed to himself to fulfill a religious duty, he proceeded to a violent exercise of persecution.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 35:6
verses.text: The bishops were driven into exile: cruelty was exerted against the clerics; and even the laity were punished, who had separated from the communion of the Arians.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 35:7
verses.text: Now, the doctrines which the Arians proclaimed were of the following nature,—that God the Father had begotten his Son for the purpose of creating the world; and that, by his power, he had made out of nothing into a new and second substance, a new and second God; and that there was a time when the Son had no existence.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 35:8
verses.text: To meet this evil, a synod was convened from the whole world to meet at Nicaea.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 35:9
verses.text: Three hundred and eighteen bishops were there assembled: the faith was fully set forth in writing; the Arian heresy was condemned; and the emperor confirmed the whole by an imperial decree.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 35:10
verses.text: The Arians, then, not daring to make any further attempt against the orthodox faith, mixed themselves among the churches, as if they acquiesced in the conclusions which had been reached, and did not hold any different opinions.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 35:11
verses.text: There remained, however, in their hearts, a deep-seated hatred against the Catholics, and they assailed, with suborned accusers and trumped-up charges, those with whom they could not contend in argument on matters of faith.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 36

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 36:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 36:2
verses.text: Accordingly, they first attack and condemn in his absence Athanasius, bishop of Alexandria, a holy man, who had been present as deacon at the Synod of Nicaea.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 36:3
verses.text: For they added to the charges which false witnesses had heaped up against him, this one, that, with wicked intentions, he had received Marcellus and Photinus, heretical priests who had been condemned by a sentence of the Synod.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 36:4
verses.text: Now, it was not doubtful as to Photinus that he had been justly condemned.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 36:5
verses.text: But in the case of Marcellus, it seemed that nothing had then been found worthy of condemnation, and a belief in his innocence was above all strengthened by the animus of that party, inasmuch as no one doubted that those same judges were heretical by whom he had been condemned.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 36:6
verses.text: But the Arians did not so much desire to get these persons out of the way as Athanasius himself.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 36:7
verses.text: Accordingly, they constrain the emperor to go so far as this, that Athanasius should be sent as an exile into Gaul.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 36:8
verses.text: But ere long, eighty bishops, assembling together in Egypt, declare that Athanasius had been unjustly condemned.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 36:9
verses.text: The matter is referred to Constantine: he orders bishops from the whole world to assemble at Sardes, and that the entire process by which Athanasius had been condemned, should be reconsidered by the council.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 36:10
verses.text: In the meantime, Constantine dies, but the Synod, called together while he was yet emperor, acquits Athanasius.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 36:11
verses.text: Marcellus, too, is restored to his bishopric, but the sentence on Photinus, bishop of Sirmion, was not rescinded; for even in the judgment of our friends, he is regarded as a heretic.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 36:12
verses.text: However, even this result chagrined Marcellus, because Photinus was known to have been his disciple in his youth.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 36:13
verses.text: But this, too, tended to secure an acquittal for Athanasius, that Ursatius and Valens, leading men among the Arians, when they were openly separated from the communion of the Church after the Synod at Sardes, entering into the presence of Julius, bishop of Rome, asked pardon of him for having condemned the innocent, and publicly declared that he had been justly acquitted by the decree of the Council of Sardes.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:2
verses.text: When, after an interval of some time had elapsed, Athanasius, finding that Marcellus was by no means sound in the faith, suspended him from communion.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:3
verses.text: And he had this degree of modesty, that, being censured by the judgment of so great a man, he voluntarily gave way.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:4
verses.text: But though at a former period innocent, yet confessedly afterwards becoming heretical, it may be allowed to conclude that he was really then guilty when judgment was pronounced regarding him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:5
verses.text: The Arians, then, finding an opportunity of that kind, conspire to subvert altogether the decrees of the Synod of Sardes.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:6
verses.text: For a certain coloring of right seemed to be furnished them in this fact, that a favorable judgment had as unjustly been formed on the side of Athanasius, as Marcellus had been improperly acquitted, since now, even in the opinion of Athanasius himself, he was deemed a heretic.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:7
verses.text: For Marcellus had stood forward as an upholder of the Sabellian heresy.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:8
verses.text: But Photinus had already brought forward a new heresy, differing indeed from Sabellius with respect to the union of the divine persons, but proclaiming that Christ had his beginning in Mary.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:9
verses.text: The Arians, therefore, with cunning design, mix up what was harmless with what was blameworthy, and embrace, under the same judgment, the condemnation of Photinus, and Marcellus, and Athanasius.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:10
verses.text: They undoubtedly did this with the view of leading the minds of the ignorant to conclude, that those had not judged incorrectly regarding Athanasius, who, it was admitted, had expressed a well-based opinion respecting Marcellus and Photinus.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:11
verses.text: At that time, however, the Arians concealed their treachery; and not daring openly to proclaim their erroneous doctrines, they professed themselves Catholics.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:12
verses.text: They thought that their first great object should be to get Athanasius turned out of the church, who had always presented a wall of opposition to their endeavors, and they hoped that, if he were removed, the rest would pass over to their evil opinion.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:13
verses.text: Now, that part of the bishops which followed the Arians accepted the condemnation of Athanasius with delight.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:14
verses.text: Another part, constrained by fear and faction, yielded to the wish of the Arian party; and only a few, to  whom the true faith was dearer than any other consideration, refused to accept their unjust judgment.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:15
verses.text: Among these was Paulinus, the bishop of Treves.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 37:16
verses.text: It is related that he, when a letter on the subject was placed before him, thus wrote, that he gave his consent to the condemnation of Photinus and Marcellus, but did not approve that of Athanasius.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 38

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 38:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 38:2
verses.text: But then the Arians, seeing that stratagem did not succeed, determined to proceed by force.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 38:3
verses.text: For it was easy for those to attempt and carry out anything who were supported by the favor of the monarch, whom they had thoroughly won over to themselves by wicked flatteries.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 38:4
verses.text: Moreover, they were by the consent of all unconquerable; for almost all the bishops of the two Pannonias, and many of the Eastern bishops, and those throughout all Asia, had joined in their unfaithfulness.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 38:5
verses.text: But the chief men in that evil company were Ursatius of Singidunum, Valens of Mursa, Theodorus of Heraclia, Stephanus of Antioch, Acatius of Caesarea, Menofantus of Ephesus, Georgius of Laodicia, and Narcissus of Neronopolis.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 38:6
verses.text: These had got possession of the palace to such an extent that the emperor did nothing without their concurrence.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 38:7
verses.text: He was indeed at the beck of all of them, but was especially under the influence of Valens.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 38:8
verses.text: For at that time, when a battle was fought at Mursa against Magnentius, Constantius had not the courage to go down to witness for himself the conflict, but took up his abode in a church of the martyrs which stood outside the town, Valens who was then the bishop of the place being with him to keep up his courage.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 38:9
verses.text: But Valens had cunningly arranged, through means of his agents, that he should be the first to be made acquainted with the result of the battle.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 38:10
verses.text: He did this either to gain the favor of the king, if he should be the first to convey to him good news, or with a view to saving his own life, since he would obtain time for flight, should the issue prove unfortunate.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 38:11
verses.text: Accordingly, the few persons who were with the king being in a state of alarm, and the emperor himself being a prey to anxiety, Valens was the first to announce to them the flight of the enemy.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 38:12
verses.text: When Constantius requested that the person who had brought the news should be introduced to his presence, Valens, to increase the reverence felt for himself, said that an angel was the messenger who had come to him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 38:13
verses.text: The emperor, who was easy of belief, was accustomed afterwards openly to declare that he had won the victory through the merits of Valens, and not by the valor of his army.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIX.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:2
verses.text: From this first proof that the prince had been won over to their side, the Arians plucked up their courage, knowing that they could make use of the power of the king, when they could make little impression by their own authority.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:3
verses.text: Accordingly, when our friends did not accept of the judgment which they had pronounced in regard to Athanasius, an edict was issued by the emperor to the effect that those who did not subscribe to the condemnation of Athanasius should be sent into banishment.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:4
verses.text: But, at that time, councils of bishops were held by our friends at Arles and Bitterae, towns situated in Gaul.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:5
verses.text: They requested that before any were compelled to subscribe against Athanasius, they should rather enter on a discussion as to the true faith; and maintained that only then was a decision to be come to respecting the point in question, when they had agreed as to the person of the judges.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:6
verses.text: But Valens and his confederates not venturing on a discussion respecting the faith, first desired to secure by force the condemnation of Athanasius.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:7
verses.text: Owing to this conflict of parties, Paulinus was driven into banishment.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:8
verses.text: In the meantime, an assembly was held at Milan, where the emperor then was; but the same controversy was there continued without any relaxation of its bitterness.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:9
verses.text: Then Eusebius, bishop of the Vercellenses, and Lucifer, bishop of Caralis in Sardinia, were exiled.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:10
verses.text: Dionysius, however, priest of Milan, subscribed to the condemnation of Athanasius, on the condition that there should be an investigation among the bishops as to the true faith.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:11
verses.text: But Valens and Ursatius, with the rest of that party, through fear of the people, who maintained the Catholic faith with extraordinary enthusiasm, did not venture to set forth in public their monstrous doctrines, but assembled within the palace.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:12
verses.text: From that place, and under the name of the emperor, they issued a letter full of all sorts of wickedness, with this purpose, no doubt, that, if the people gave it a favorable hearing, they should then bring forward, under public authority, the things which they desired; but if it should be received otherwise, that all the ill feeling might be directed against the king, while his mistake might be regarded as excusable, because being then only a catechumen, he might readily be supposed to have erred concerning the mysteries of the faith.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:13
verses.text: Well, when the letter was read in the church, the people expressed their aversion to it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:14
verses.text: And Dionysius, because he did not concur with them, was banished from the city, while Auxentius was immediately chosen as  bishop in his place.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:15
verses.text: Liberius, too, bishop of the city of Rome, and Hilarius, bishop of Poictiers, were driven into exile.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:16
verses.text: Rhodanius, also, bishop of Toulouse (who, being by nature of a softer disposition, had resisted the Arians, not so much from his own powers as from his fellowship with Hilarius) was involved in the same punishment.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:17
verses.text: All these persons, however, were prepared to suspend Athanasius from communion, only in order that an inquiry might be instituted among the bishops as to the true faith.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:18
verses.text: But it seemed best to the Arians to withdraw the most celebrated men from the controversy.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:19
verses.text: Accordingly, those whom we have mentioned above were driven into exile, forty-five years ago, when Arbitio and Lollianus were consuls.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:20
verses.text: Liberius, however, was, a little afterwards, restored to the city, in consequence of the disturbances at Rome.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 39:21
verses.text: But it is well known that the persons exiled were celebrated by the admiration of the whole world, and that abundant supplies of money were collected to meet their wants, while they were visited by deputies of the Catholic people from almost all the provinces.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 40

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 40:1
verses.text: Chapter XL.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 40:2
verses.text: In the meantime, the Arians, not secretly, as before, but openly and publicly proclaimed their monstrous heretical doctrines.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 40:3
verses.text: Moreover, they interpreted after their own views the Synod of Nicaea, and by the addition of one letter to its finding, threw a sort of obscurity over the truth.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 40:4
verses.text: For where the expression Homoousion had been written, which denotes "of one substance," they maintained that it was written Homoiousion, which simply means "of like substance".

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 40:5
verses.text: They thus granted a likeness, but took away unity; for likeness is very different from unity; just as, for illustration's sake, a picture of a human body might be like a man, and yet possess nothing of the reality of a man.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 40:6
verses.text: But some of them went even farther, and maintained Anomoiousia, that is, an unlike substance.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 40:7
verses.text: And to such a pitch did these controversies extend, that the wide world was involved in these monstrous errors.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 40:8
verses.text: For Valens and Ursatius, with their supporters, whose names we have stated, infected Italy, Illyria, and the East with these opinions.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 40:9
verses.text: Saturninus, bishop of Arles, a violent and factious man, harassed our country of Gaul in like manner.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 40:10
verses.text: There was also a prevalent belief that Osius from Spain had gone over to the same unfaithful party, which appears all the more wonderful and incredible on this account, that he had been, almost during his whole life, the most determined upholder of our views, and the Synod of Nice was regarded as having been held at his instigation.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 40:11
verses.text: If he did go over, the reason may have been that in his extreme old age (for he was then more than a centenarian, as St.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 40:12
verses.text: Hilarius relates in his epistles) he had fallen into dotage.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 40:13
verses.text: While the world was disturbed by these things, and the churches were languishing as if from a sort of disease, an anxiety, less exciting indeed, but no less serious, pressed upon the emperor, that although the Arians, whom he favored, appeared the stronger, yet there was still no agreement among the bishops concerning the faith.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:1
verses.text: Chapter XLI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:2
verses.text: Accordingly, the emperor orders a Synod to assemble at Ariminum, a city of Italy, and instructs Taurus the prefect, not to let them separate, after they were once assembled, until they should agree as to one faith, at the same time promising him the consulship, if he carried the affair to a successful termination.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:3
verses.text: Imperial officers, therefore, being sent through Illyria, Italy, Africa, and the two Gauls, four hundred and rather more Western bishops were summoned or compelled to assemble at Ariminum; and for all of these the emperor had ordered provisions and lodgings to be provided.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:4
verses.text: But that appeared unseemly to the men of our part of the world, that is, to the Aquitanians, the Gauls, and Britons, so that refusing the public supplies, they preferred to live at their own expense.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:5
verses.text: Three only of those from Britain, through want of means of their own, made use of the public bounty, after having refused contributions offered by the rest; for they thought it more dutiful to burden the public treasury than individuals.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:6
verses.text: I have heard that Gavidius, our bishop, was accustomed to refer to this conduct in a censuring sort of way, but I would be inclined to judge far otherwise; and I hold it matter of admiration that the bishops had nothing of their own, while they did not accept assistance from others rather than from the public treasury, so that they burdened nobody.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:7
verses.text: In both points, they thus furnished us with noble example.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:8
verses.text: Nothing worthy of mention is recorded of the others; but I return to the subject in hand.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:9
verses.text: After all the bishops had been collected together, as we have said, a separation of parties took place.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:10
verses.text: Our friends take possession of the church, while the Arians select, as a place for prayer, a temple which was then intentionally standing empty.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:11
verses.text: But these did not amount to more than eighty persons: the rest belonged to our party.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:12
verses.text: Well, after frequent meetings had been held, nothing was really  accomplished, our friends continuing in the faith, and the others not abandoning their unfaithfulness.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:13
verses.text: At length it was resolved to send ten deputies to the emperor, that he might learn what was the faith or opinion of the parties, and might know that there could be no peace with heretics.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:14
verses.text: The Arians do the same thing, and send a like number of deputies, who should contend with our friends in the presence of the emperor.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:15
verses.text: But on the part of our people, young men of but little learning and little prudence had been selected; while, on the side of the Arians, old men were sent, skillful and abounding in talent, thoroughly imbued, too, with their old unfaithful doctrines; and these easily got the upper hand with the prince.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 41:16
verses.text: But our friends had been specially charged not to enter into any kind of communion with the Arians, and to reserve every point, in its entirety, for discussion in a Synod.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 42

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 42:1
verses.text: Chapter XLII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 42:2
verses.text: In the meantime in the East, after the example of the West, the emperor ordered almost all the bishops to assemble at Seleucia, a town of Isauria.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 42:3
verses.text: At that time, Hilarius, who was now spending the fourth year of his exile in Phrygia, is compelled to be present among the other bishops, the means of a public conveyance being furnished to him by the lieutenant and governor.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 42:4
verses.text: As, however, the emperor had given no special orders regarding him, the judges, simply following the general order by which they were commanded to gather all bishops to the council, sent him also among the rest who were willing to go.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 42:5
verses.text: This was done, as I imagine, by the special ordination of God, in order that a man who was most deeply instructed in divine things, might be present when a discussion was to be carried on respecting the faith.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 42:6
verses.text: He, on arriving at Seleucia, was received with great favor, and drew the minds and affections of all towards himself.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 42:7
verses.text: His first inquiry was as to the real faith of the Gauls, because at that time the Arians had spread evil reports regarding us, and we were held suspected by the Easterns as having embraced the belief of Sabellius, to the effect that the unity of the one God was simply distinguished by a threefold name.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 42:8
verses.text: But after he had set forth his faith in harmony with those conclusions which had been reached by the fathers at Nicaea, he bore his testimony in favor of the Westerns.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 42:9
verses.text: Thus the minds of all having been satisfied, he was admitted to communion, and being also received into alliance, was added to the council.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 42:10
verses.text: They then proceeded to actual work, and the originators of the wicked heresy being discovered, were separated from the body of the Church.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 42:11
verses.text: In that number were Georgius of Alexandria, Acacius, Eudoxius, Vranius, Leontius, Theodosius, Evagrius, Theodulus.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 42:12
verses.text: But when the Synod was over, an embassy was appointed to go to the emperor and make him acquainted with what had been done.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 42:13
verses.text: Those who had been condemned also went to the prince, relying upon the power of their confederates, and a common cause with the monarch.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 43

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 43:1
verses.text: Chapter XLIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 43:2
verses.text: In the meantime, the emperor compels those deputies of our party who had been sent from the council at Ariminum to join in communion with the heretics.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 43:3
verses.text: At the same time, he hands them a confession of faith which had been drawn up by these wicked men, and which, being expressed in deceptive terms, seemed to exhibit the Catholic faith, while unfaithfulness secretly lay hid in it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 43:4
verses.text: For under an appearance of false reasoning, it abolished the use of the word Ousia as being ambiguous, and as having been too hastily adopted by the fathers, while it rested upon no Scriptural authority.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 43:5
verses.text: The object of this was that the Son might not be believed to be of one substance with the Father.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 43:6
verses.text: The same confession of faith acknowledged that the Son was like the Father.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 43:7
verses.text: But deception was carefully prepared within the words, in order that he might be like, but not equal.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 43:8
verses.text: Thus, the deputies being sent away, orders were given to the prefect that he should not dissolve the Synod, until all professed by their subscriptions their agreement to the declaration of faith which had been drawn up; and if any should hold back with excessive obstinacy, they should be driven into banishment, provided their number did not amount to fifteen.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 43:9
verses.text: But when the deputies returned, they were refused communion, although they pleaded the force which had been brought to bear upon them by the king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 43:10
verses.text: For when it was discovered what had been decreed, greater disturbance arose in their affairs and purposes.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 43:11
verses.text: Then by degrees numbers of our people, partly overcome through the weakness of their character, and partly influenced by the thought of a weary journeying into foreign lands, surrendered to the opposite party.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 43:12
verses.text: These were now, on the return of the deputies, the stronger of the two bodies, and had taken possession of the church, our friends being driven out of it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 43:13
verses.text: And when the minds of our people once began to incline in that direction, they rushed  in flocks over to the other side, until the number of our friends was diminished down to twenty.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:1
verses.text: Chapter XLIV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:2
verses.text: But these, the fewer they became, showed themselves all the more powerful; as the most steadfast among them was to be reckoned our friend Foegadius, and Servatio, bishop of the Tungri.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:3
verses.text: As these had not yielded to threats and terrors, Taurus assails them with entreaties, and beseeches them with tears to adopt milder counsels.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:4
verses.text: He argued that the bishops were now in the seventh month since they had been shut up within one city—that no hope of returning home presented itself to them, worn out by the inclemency of winter and positive want; and what then would be the end? He urged them to follow the example of the majority, and to derive authority for so doing at least from the numbers who had preceded them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:5
verses.text: For Foegadius openly declared that he was prepared for banishment, and for every kind of punishment that might be assigned him, but would not accept that confession of faith which had been drawn up by the Arians.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:6
verses.text: Thus several days passed in this sort of discussion.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:7
verses.text: And when they made little progress towards a pacification, by degrees Foegadius began to yield, and at the last was overcome by a proposal which was made to him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:8
verses.text: For Valens and Ursatius affirmed that the present confession of faith was drawn up on the lines of Catholic doctrine, and having been brought forward by the Easterns at the instigation of the emperor, could not be rejected without impiety; and what possible end of strife could there be if a confession which satisfied the Easterns was rejected by those of the West? Finally, if there appeared anything less fully stated in the present confession than was desirable, they themselves should add what they thought ought to be added, and that they, for their part, would acquiesce in those things which might be added.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:9
verses.text: This friendly profession was received with favorable minds by all.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:10
verses.text: Nor did our people venture any longer to make opposition, desiring as they did in some way or other now to put an end to the business.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:11
verses.text: Then confessions drawn up by Foegadius and Servatio began to be published; and in these first Arius and his whole unfaithful scheme was condemned, while the Son of God also was pronounced equal to the Father, and without beginning, [that is] without any commencement in time.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:12
verses.text: Then Valens, as if assisting our friends, subjoined the statement (in which there lurked a secret guile) that the Son of God was not a creature like the other creatures; and the deceit involved in this declaration escaped the notice of the hearers.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:13
verses.text: For in these words, in which the Son was denied to be like the other creatures, he was nevertheless pronounced a creature, only superior to the rest.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:14
verses.text: Thus neither party could hold that it had wholly conquered or had wholly been conquered, since the confession itself was in favor of the Arians, but the declarations afterwards added were in favor of our friends.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:15
verses.text: That one, however, must be excepted which Valens had subjoined, and which, not being at the time understood, was at length comprehended when it was too late.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 44:16
verses.text: In this way, at any rate, the council was brought to an end, a council which had a good beginning but a disgraceful conclusion.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:1
verses.text: Chapter XLV.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:2
verses.text: Thus, then, the Arians, with their affairs in a very flourishing condition, and everything turning out according to their wishes, go in a body to Constantinople where the emperor was.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:3
verses.text: There they found the deputies from the Synod of Seleucia, and compel them by an exercise of the royal power to follow the example of the Westerns, and accept that heretical confession of faith.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:4
verses.text: Numbers who refused were tortured with painful imprisonment and hunger, so that at length they yielded their conscience captive.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:5
verses.text: But many who resisted more courageously, being deprived of their bishoprics, were driven into exile, and others substituted in their place.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:6
verses.text: Thus, the best priests being either terrified by threats, or driven into exile, all gave way before the unfaithfulness of a few.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:7
