verses.text: Hilarius was there at the time, having followed the deputies from Seleucia; and as no certain orders had been given regarding him, he was waiting on the will of the emperor to see whether perchance he should be ordered to return into banishment.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:8
verses.text: When he perceived the extreme danger into which the faith had been brought, inasmuch as the Westerns had been beguiled, and the Easterns were being overcome by means of wickedness, he, in three papers publicly presented, begged an audience of the king, in order that he might debate on points of faith in the presence of his adversaries.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:9
verses.text: But the Arians opposed that to the utmost extent of their ability.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:10
verses.text: Finally, Hilarius was ordered to return to Gaul, as being a sower of discord, and a troubler of the East, while the sentence of exile against him remained uncanceled.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:11
verses.text: But when he had wandered over almost the whole earth which was infected  with the evil of unfaithfulness, his mind was full of doubt and deeply agitated with the mighty burden of cares which pressed upon it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:12
verses.text: Perceiving that it seemed good to many not to enter into communion with those who had acknowledged the Synod of Ariminum, he thought the best thing he could do was to bring back all to repentance and reformation.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:13
verses.text: In frequent councils within Gaul, and while almost all the bishops publicly owned the error that had been committed, he condemns the proceedings at Ariminum, and frames anew the faith of the churches after its pristine form.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:14
verses.text: Saturninus, however, bishop of Arles, who was, in truth, a very bad man, of an evil and corrupt character, resisted these sound measures.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:15
verses.text: He was, in fact, a man who, besides the infamy of being a heretic, was convicted of many unspeakable crimes, and cast out of the Church.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:16
verses.text: Thus, having lost its leader, the strength of the party opposed to Hilarius was broken.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:17
verses.text: Paternus also of Petrocorii, equally infatuated, and not shrinking from openly professing unfaithfulness, was expelled from the priesthood: pardon was extended to the others.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:18
verses.text: This fact is admitted by all, that our regions of Gaul were set free from the guilt of heresy through the kind efforts of Hilarius alone.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:19
verses.text: But Lucifer, who was then at Antioch held a very different opinion.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:20
verses.text: For he condemned those who assembled at Ariminum to such an extent, that he even separated himself from the communion of those who had received them as friends, after they had made satisfaction or exhibited penitence.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:21
verses.text: Whether this resolution of his was right or wrong, I will not take upon me to say.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 45:22
verses.text: Paulinus and Rhodanius died in Phrygia; Hilarius died in his native country in the sixth year after his return.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:2
verses.text: There follow the times of our own day, both difficult and dangerous.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:3
verses.text: In these the churches have been defiled with no ordinary evil, and all things thrown into confusion.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:4
verses.text: For then, for the first time, the infamous heresy of the Gnostics was detected in Spain—a deadly superstition which concealed itself under mystic rites.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:5
verses.text: The birthplace of that mischief was the East, and specially Egypt, but from what beginnings it there sprang up and increased is not easy to explain.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:6
verses.text: Marcus was the first to introduce it into Spain, having set out from Egypt, his birthplace being Memphis.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:7
verses.text: His pupils were a certain Agape, a woman of no mean origin, and a rhetorician named Helpidius.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:8
verses.text: By these again Priscillian was instructed, a man of noble birth, of great riches, bold, restless, eloquent, learned through much reading, very ready at debate and discussion—in fact, altogether a happy man, if he had not ruined an excellent intellect by wicked studies.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:9
verses.text: Undoubtedly, there were to be seen in him many admirable qualities both of mind and body.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:10
verses.text: He was able to spend much time in watchfulness, and to endure both hunger and thirst; he had little desire for amassing wealth, and he was most economical in the use of it.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:11
verses.text: But at the same time he was a very vain man, and was much more puffed up than he ought to have been with the knowledge of mere earthly things: moreover, it was believed that he had practised magical arts from his boyhood.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:12
verses.text: He, after having himself adopted the pernicious system referred to, drew into its acceptance many persons of noble rank and multitudes of the common people by the arts of persuasion and flattery which he possessed.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:13
verses.text: Besides this, women who were fond of novelties and of unstable faith, as well as of a prurient curiosity in all things, flocked to him in crowds.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:14
verses.text: It increased this tendency that he exhibited, a kind of humility in his countenance and manner, and thus excited in all a greater honor and respect for himself.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:15
verses.text: And now by degrees the wasting disorder of that heresy had pervaded the most of Spain, and even some of the bishops came under its depraving influence.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:16
verses.text: Among these, Instantius and Salvianus had taken up the cause of Priscillian, not only by expressing their concurrence in his views, but even by binding themselves to him with a kind of oath.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:17
verses.text: This went on until Hyginus, bishop of Cordova, who dwelt in the vicinity, found out how matters stood, and reported the whole to Ydacius, priest of Emerita.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 46:18
verses.text: But he, by harassing Instantius and his confederates without measure, and beyond what the occasion called for, applied, as it were, a torch to the growing conflagration, so that he rather exasperated than suppressed these evil men.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 47

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 47:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 47:2
verses.text: So, then, after many controversies among them, which are not worthy of mention, a Synod was assembled at Saragossa, at which even the Aquitanian bishops were present.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 47:3
verses.text: But the heretics did not venture to submit themselves to the judgment of the council; sentence, however, was passed against them in their absence, and Instantius and Salvianus, bishops, with Helpidius and Priscillian, laymen, were condemned.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 47:4
verses.text: It was also added that if any one should admit the  condemned persons to communion, he should understand that the same sentence would be pronounced against himself.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 47:5
verses.text: And the duty was entrusted to Ithacius, bishop of Sossuba, of seeing that the decree of the bishops was brought to the knowledge of all, and that Hyginus especially should be excluded from communion, who, though he had been the first to commence open proceedings against the heretics, had afterwards fallen away shamefully and admitted them to communion.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 47:6
verses.text: In the meantime, Instantius and Salvianus, having been condemned by the judgment of the priests, appoint as bishop in the town of Arles, Priscillian, a layman indeed, but the leader in all these troubles, and who had been condemned along with themselves in the Synod at Saragossa.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 47:7
verses.text: This they did with the view of adding to their strength, doubtless imagining that, if they armed with sacerdotal authority a man of bold and subtle character, they would find themselves in a safer position.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 47:8
verses.text: But then Ydacius and Ithacius pressed forward their measures more ardently, in the belief that the mischief might be suppressed at its beginning.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 47:9
verses.text: With unwise counsels, however, they applied to secular judges, that by their decrees and prosecutions the heretics might be expelled from the cities.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 47:10
verses.text: Accordingly, after many disgraceful squabbles, a rescript was, on the entreaty of Ydacius, obtained from Gratianus, who was then emperor, in virtue of which all heretics were enjoined not only to leave churches or cities, but to be driven forth beyond all the territory under his jurisdiction.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 47:11
verses.text: When this edict became known, the Gnostics, distrusting their own affairs, did not venture to oppose the judgment, but those of them who bore the name of bishops gave way of their own accord, while fear scattered the rest.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 48

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 48:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVIII.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 48:2
verses.text: And then Instantius, Salvianus, and Priscillian set out for Rome, in order that before Damasus who was at that time the bishop of the city, they might clear themselves of the charges brought against them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 48:3
verses.text: Well, their journey led them through the heart of Aquitania, and being there received with great pomp by such as knew no better, they spread the seeds of their heresy.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 48:4
verses.text: Above all, they perverted by their evil teachings the people of Elusa, who were then of a good and religious disposition.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 48:5
verses.text: They were driven forth from Bordeaux by Delfinus, yet lingering for a little while in the territory of Euchrotia, they infected some with their errors.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 48:6
verses.text: They then pursued the journey on which they had entered, attended by a base and shameful company, among whom were their wives and even strange women.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 48:7
verses.text: In the number of these was Euchrotia and her daughter Procula, of the latter of whom there was a common report that, when pregnant through adultery with Priscillian, she procured abortion by the use of certain plants.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 48:8
verses.text: When they reached Rome with the wish of clearing themselves before Damasus, they were not even admitted to his presence.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 48:9
verses.text: Returning to Milan, they found that Ambrose was equally opposed to them.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 48:10
verses.text: Then they changed their plans, with the view that, as they had not got the better of the two bishops, who were at that time possessed of the highest authority, they might, by bribery and flattery, obtain what they desired from the emperor.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 48:11
verses.text: Accordingly, having won over Macedonius, who was the master of public services, they procured a rescript, by which, those decrees which had formerly been made being trampled under foot, they were ordered to be restored to their churches.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 48:12
verses.text: Relying upon this, Instantius and Priscillian made their wayback to Spain (for Salvianus had died in the city); and they then, without any struggle, recovered the churches over which they had ruled.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49:1
verses.text: Chapter XLIX.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49:2
verses.text: But the power, not the will, to resist, failed Ithacius; for the heretics had won over by bribes Voluentius, the proconsul, and thus consolidated their own power.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49:3
verses.text: Moreover, Ithacius was put on his trial, by these men as being a disturber of the churches, and he having been ordered as the result of a fierce prosecution, to be carried off as a prisoner, fled in terror into Gaul, where he betook himself to Gregory the prefect.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49:4
verses.text: He, after he learned what had taken place, orders the authors of these tumults to be brought before himself, and makes a report on all that had occurred to the emperor, in order that he might close against the heretics every means of flattery or bribery.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49:5
verses.text: But that was done in vain; because, through the licentiousness and power of a few, all things were there to be purchased.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49:6
verses.text: Accordingly, the heretics by their artifices, having presented Macedonius with a large sum of money, secure that, by the imperial authority, the hearing of the trial was taken from the prefect, and transferred to the lieutenant in Spain.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49:7
verses.text: By that time, the Spaniards had ceased to have a proconsul as ruler, and officials were sent by the Master to bring back to Spain Ithacius who was then living at Treves.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49:8
verses.text: He, however, craftily escaped them, and being subsequently defended by the bishop Pritannius, he set them at  defiance.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49:9
verses.text: Then, too, a faint rumor had spread that Maximus had assumed imperial power in Britain, and would, in a short time, make an incursion into Gaul.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49:10
verses.text: Accordingly, Ithacius then resolved, although his affairs were in a ticklish state, to wait the arrival of the new emperor; and that, in the meantime, no step should on his part be taken.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49:11
verses.text: When therefore Maximus, as victor, entered the town of the Treveri, he poured forth entreaties full of ill-will and accusations against Priscillian and his confederates.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49:12
verses.text: The emperor influenced by these statements sent letters to the prefect of Gaul and to the lieutenant in Spain, ordering that all whom that disgraceful heresy had affected should be brought to a Synod at Bordeaux.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49:13
verses.text: Accordingly, Instantius and Priscillian were escorted thither and, of these, Instantius was enjoined to plead his cause; and after he was found unable to clear himself, he was pronounced unworthy of the office of a bishop.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49:14
verses.text: But Priscillian, in order that he might avoid being heard by the bishops, appealed to the emperor.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 49:15
verses.text: And that was permitted to be done through the want of resolution on the part of our friends, who ought either to have passed a sentence even against one who resisted it, or, if they were regarded as themselves suspicious persons, should have reserved the hearing for other bishops, and should not have transferred to the emperor a cause involving such manifest offences.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:1
verses.text: Chapter L.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:2
verses.text: Thus, then, all whom the process embraced were brought before the king.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:3
verses.text: The bishops Ydacius and Ithacius followed as accusers; and I would by no means blame their zeal in overthrowing heretics, if they had not contended for victory with greater keenness than was fitting.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:4
verses.text: And my feeling indeed is, that the accusers were as distasteful to me as the accused.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:5
verses.text: I certainly hold that Ithacius had no worth or holiness about him.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:6
verses.text: For he was a bold, loquacious, impudent, and extravagant man; excessively devoted to the pleasures of sensuality.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:7
verses.text: He proceeded even to such a pitch of folly as to charge all those men, however holy, who either took delight in reading, or made it their object to vie with each other in the practice of fasting, with being friends or disciples of Priscillian.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:8
verses.text: The miserable wretch even ventured publicly to bring forward a disgraceful charge of heresy against Martin, who was at that time a bishop, and a man clearly worthy of being compared to the Apostles.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:9
verses.text: For Martin, being then settled at Treves, did not cease to importune Ithacius, that he should give up his accusations, or to implore Maximus that he should not shed the blood of the unhappy persons in question.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:10
verses.text: He maintained that it was quite sufficient punishment that, having been declared heretics by a sentence of the bishops, they should have been expelled from the churches; and that it was, besides, a foul and unheard-of indignity, that a secular ruler should be judge in an ecclesiastical cause.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:11
verses.text: And, in fact, as long as Martin survived, the trial was put off; while, when he was about to leave this world, he, by his remarkable influence, obtained a promise from Maximus, that no cruel measure would be resolved on with respect to the guilty persons.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:12
verses.text: But subsequently, the emperor being led astray by Magnus and Rufus, and turned from the milder course which Martin had counseled, entrusted the case to the prefect Evodius, a man of stern and severe character.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:13
verses.text: He tried Priscillian in two assemblies, and convicted him of evil conduct.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:14
verses.text: In fact, Priscillian did not deny that he had given himself up to lewd doctrines; had been accustomed to hold, by night, gatherings of vile women, and to pray in a state of nudity.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:15
verses.text: Accordingly, Evodius pronounced him guilty, and sent him back to prison, until he had time to consult the emperor.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 50:16
verses.text: The matter, then, in all its details, was reported to the palace, and the emperor decreed that Priscillian and his friends should be put to death.

chapters.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:1
verses.text: Chapter LI.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:2
verses.text: But Ithacius, seeing how much ill-will it would excite against him among the bishops, if he should stand forth as accuser also at the last trial on a capital charge (for it was requisite that the trial should be repeated), withdrew from the prosecution.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:3
verses.text: His cunning, however, in thus acting was in vain, as the mischief was already accomplished.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:4
verses.text: Well, a certain Patricius, an advocate connected with the treasury, was then appointed accuser by Maximus.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:5
verses.text: Accordingly, under him as prosecutor, Priscillian was condemned to death, and along with him, Felicissimus and Armenius, who, when they were clerics, had lately adopted the cause of Priscillian, and revolted from the Catholics.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:6
verses.text: Latronianus, too, and Euchrotia were beheaded.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:7
verses.text: Instantius, who, as we have said above, had been condemned by the bishops, was transported to the island of Sylina which lies beyond Britain.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:8
verses.text: A process was then instituted against the others in trials which followed, and Asarivus, and Aurelius the deacon, were condemned to be beheaded, while Tiberianus was deprived of his goods, and banished  to the island of Sylina.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:9
verses.text: Tertullus, Potamius, and Joannes, as being persons of less consideration, and worthy of some merciful treatment, inasmuch as before the trial they had made a confession, both as to themselves and their confederates, were sentenced to a temporary banishment into Gaul.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:10
verses.text: In this sort of way, men who were most unworthy of the light of day, were, in order that they might serve as a terrible example to others, either put to death or punished with exile.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:11
verses.text: That conduct which he had at first defended by his right of appeal to the tribunals, and by regard to the public good, Ithacius, harassed with invectives, and at last overcome, threw the blame of upon those, by whose direction and counsels he had effected his object.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:12
verses.text: Yet he was the only one of all of them who was thrust out of the episcopate.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:13
verses.text: For Ydacius, although less guilty, had voluntarily resigned his bishopric: that was wisely and respectfully done, had he not afterward spoiled the credit of such a step by endeavoring to recover the position which had been lost.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:14
verses.text: Well, after the death of Priscillian, not only was the heresy not suppressed, which, under him, as its author, had burst forth, but acquiring strength, it became more widely spread.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:15
verses.text: For his followers who had previously honored him as a saint, subsequently began to reverence him as a martyr.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:16
verses.text: The bodies of those who had been put to death were conveyed to Spain, and their funerals were celebrated with great pomp.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:17
verses.text: Nay, it came to be thought the highest exercise of religion to swear by Priscillian.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:18
verses.text: But between them and our friends, a perpetual war of quarreling has been kept up.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:19
verses.text: And that conflict, after being sustained for fifteen years with horrible dissension, could not by any means be set at rest.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:20
verses.text: And now all things were seen to be disturbed and confused by the discord, especially of the bishops, while everything was corrupted by them through their hatred, partiality, fear, faithlessness, envy, factiousness, lust, avarice, pride, sleepiness, and inactivity.

verses.name: Sulpitius Severus: Sacred History Book II 51:21
verses.text: In a word, a large number were striving with insane plans and obstinate inclinations against a few giving wise counsel: while, in the meantime, the people of God, and all the excellent of the earth were exposed to mockery and insult.
